country:
None
text:
This turned out to be a pleasant surprise. Here are the changes I made to what is now my favorite dish. In the gravy, I used a can of French Onion soup as well as a can of Cream of Mushroom and a packet of Dry Onion Soup. I omitted the salt due to the high sodium content in the soups.  I'm glad I did. I doubled the gravy except for the ketchup...kept it at 1/4 cup while doubling the rest.  I also added a jar of mushrooms to the gravy.  After browning each side of the patties (and yes, having them fall apart slightly), I transferred the patties to a foil-lined casserole dish, put the gravy on top, covered the dish, and cooked it at 375 for 45 minutes.  I was worried the patties wouldn't get all the way done because they were pretty thick, but they turned out perfect!!! We had it with brown rice (and had just enough wonderful gravy to go along with it!) and steamed broccoli. This is a new favorite recipe for my husband and me.

text:
The "steaks" themselves were tasty (heavily altered with additional seasonings).  My steaks held their shape quite well.  I cooked 1/2 batch on the stove and another batch in the oven... preferred the taste of the stove cooked batch, but the oven cooked batch tasted good too.  

The great disappointment with this recipe was the sauce - it was horrible, to put it kindly!  I followed the advice of others to drastically cut the ketchup - but it didn't do much for the flavor.  It was far from authentic tasting.  I had extra patties and no sauce (not that I would have used the sauce anyway) - the next day I decided to try using Liptons Mushroom and Onion soup mix for the gravy.  I followed the package instructions for making gravy... DELICIOUS!  It was hands down the best tasting sauce for salisbury steak and so simple to make.    

So, if you're craving an old cafeteria food favorite - don't waste your time with the recipe for the sauce - buy a box of Lipton Mushroom Onion soup mix and make the gravy with it - you won't regret it!

text:
The only reason I gave this recipe four stars is because I ended up doing a lot of tweaking based on other recommendations.  I ended up with a WONDERFUL meal.  I took the following suggestions: I added chopped onion and garlic to meat mixture before browning.  I added a can of cream of mushroom soup to French onion soup, and mixed in a small amount of brown gravy mix to give it some color and thickened it up a bit.  I omitted the ketchup and doubled the amount to pour on top of garlic mashed potatoes.  For those who had trouble keeping the patties together, try this as was suggested before.  Instead of cooking in a skillet, place browned patties in a foil-lined casserole dish, pour gravy over top, and bake at 400 for 30 mins.  Your patties will stay together nicely!!

text:
I made this recipe a couple of times "as is" - Will give 3 1/2 ***.  Did not like the ketchup and not enough gravy.  After a few modifications... FIVE STARS *****!  Here are the modifications I make each time now (thanks to a compilation of others' suggestions on this site):  1.) Chop up one medium onion (fine) and mix it with the hamburger  2.)  I used 3 TBL Crisco to brown the steaks in the pan (and then drained before I added the gravy 2.) Double the gravy ingredients and omit the ketchup completely 3.) Add 1 can Mushroom Soup, 1 Pkg. Lipton's Dry Onion Soup Mix and 1/2 Cup brown gravy (I use Campbell's most of the time, but any brand works fine).  I prepare the steaks on the stove (don't use the oven as some have suggested), and they turn out perfectly.  Serve with mashed potatoes, fresh green beans and Romaine Salad (with dried cherries or cranberries).  Yummy!

Didn't have a can of condensed onion soup, so I subbed a packet of Lipton's Onion Soup.  Threw in sauteed mushrooms I had in the fridge which gave more flavor to the dish. city:

country:
None
text:
These were great with a few changes. I used closer to 2 ½ lbs of ground beef. Added almost a half a can of the French onion soup. Still added one egg, used seasoned bread crumbs instead of plain, more than a ½ a cup just enough to get my meat from being to watery. I added no salt to this and ½ teaspoon of pepper. I put this meat mixture in a container and in the fridge for an hour. I think this helped to combine the flavors. Then I shaped these into elongated patties about a half an inch thick or more. Then I put 2 tablespoons of butter into a pan on medium heat and brown the patties. My patties did not fall apart. I took out the patties and whisked in almost a ¼ cup of flour to the butter. This helped me get a thick sauce then added one and a half a can of French onion soup. You don’t need to add the other whole can of French onion soup but this makes lots of gravy for mashed potatoes. I added 1 squirt of mustard ¼ cup of Worcestershire sauce and 2 squirts of ketchup and half a cup of water or so. I let this boil for 2-3 minutes to thicken up then add my patties into the sauce and lower the heat to medium low for about 15-20 minutes covered. I don’t measure anything or time anything but I’ve made this several times and it comes out wonderful. The meat comes out very moist I will make meatballs next as an appetizer or even a meatloaf would excellent. My boyfriend and his family love it and there are never leftovers. Hope this helps.

country:

text:
Excellent recipe to work from, even my picky son loved this.  I browned the steaks in a pan then put them in the crock pot.  I poured off most of the grease from the pan, sprinkled a tablespoon or so of flour and cooked it for one minute.  Stirred in one can of french onion soup, one can of cream of mushroom soup, a can of beef broth and a package of Lipton onion soup mix.  Added a few shakes of Worcester and cooked until hot.  Poured this over the steaks in the crock pot and cooked for 3 hours on low.  The meat is melt-in-your-mouth tender, the gravy flavorful and plentiful enough to serve over mashed potatoes.  Topped the steaks off with mushrooms sauteed in butter and garlic.  I was afraid the gravy would be way too salty even though I added NO additional salt, but it wasn't.  I'm not a person who salts her food and I found it just right.

text:
If you are having trouble with the patties falling apart, form them and then put in the fridge until firm.  Also to make more sauce (gravy) to serve over mashed potatoes or noodles, dissolve 1 or 2 beef bouillon cubes in a cup of hot water to add to the dish. Thicken with some corn starch to desired consistency and adjust seasonings accordingly.

text:
When I told my husband what we were having for dinner last night he was less than thrilled, until he tasted it that is.  His response was "this is GREAT."  

As I almost always do I changed the recipe to fit our family. I made the "steaks" almost exactly as listed except I omited the salt.  Too much sodium in the soup. I also added garlic powder and onion powder.  I pan fried just to sear them and then moved to the oven. 

For the sauce I sauteed mushrooms and onions.  I then mixed the remaining soup, double the flour, 1/2 package of McCormick au jus mix, 1 can of water and garlic powder. I reduced the ketchup to 1 tsp and the worchestershire sauce to two drops. I stirred until thicken and poured over the steaks in the oven.  Baked about 30 minutes and I agree with my husband they were great.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I made several changes to this recipe due to the comments of others.  The recipe really turned out great.  My brother, the very picky person he is said this is by far the best Salisbury Steak he has ever had.  I put 2 Tbsp of the canned French Onion soup into the meat mixture and used 3/4 cup of fresh bread crumbs instead of dry.  I also put 1/2 pkg Lipton Onion Soup mix and a teaspoon of Worcestershire directly into the meat along with 1/4 tsp of dry mustard.  Used the rest of the ingredients for the meat mixture as in the recipe omitting the salt.  For the gravy after browning, used the rest of the canned soup, only 1 Tbsp of ketchup, 1 Tbsp Worcestershire, 1/2 tsp dry mustard, 1/4 cup water, 1 beef bouillon cube (Knorr), and 1 small can mushrooms.  I used cornstarch for thickening instead of flour.  It didn't take much.  This is an excellent basic recipe!

city:

text:
Followed the recipe as called for.  The steak was absolutely delicious and tender.  The sauce...not so much.  I am glad that I tasted the sauce before adding it to the pan or I would have been upset.  The sauce tastes like a meatloaf topping that I make.   I just didn't care for it at all.  Thank goodness I had a pack of brown gravy mix and a jar of beef gravy in order to rescue the meal.  I will make this again without the sauce the recipe calls for.

On a side note, as I prepared the recipe for 8 servings, I browned all steaks in the skillet.  Before adding the gravies, I put half of the steaks in a casserole dish.  Poured the gravy over the steaks.  The steaks cooked in the oven were baked for 25 minutes at 350* and the remaining steaks were cooked on the stove top as directed.  The stove top steaks had the better flavor while the oven steaks had a more appealing look to them.

In some ways, I almost feel the single star rating is unfair.  But this is a recipe in which one half is adequate, and the other I just didn't care for at all. text:
This came out very tender and quite flavorful. It was fast, and the adults liked it, but the site of all of those onions turned the kids right off. I would make this again, but I would substitute a rehydrated package of dry onion soup mix. (In one cup water.) That way, I can add the onions to the meat mix, and leave them out of the gravy without losing flavor. Also, I would decrease the ketchup to 1/4 c. or so (too much tomato smell, kids thought it was meatloaf!) and add some beef broth or boullion.

My family loved these. I made exactly as recipe stated the first time but, reduced the ketchup on the second batch, because we preferred a more beefy flavor to the tomato taste. As others had suggested, I used a can of cream of mushroom and added a jar of mushrooms to the gravy. I used Italian bread crumbs for more flavor. Soooo good. Thanks again.

text:
I made some pretty big changes to this but the result was so good I'm giving this base recipe 5 stars.  I used about 2 1/2 lbs. ground beef and got 8 patties.  I increased the amount of soup to 2/3 cup but kept all other measurements as written.  For the gravy I mixed together the remaining French onion soup, one can of cream of mushroom soup, 1 cup beef broth and the remaining ingredients as stated but omitted the flour and worcestershire sauce.  This gives you a decent amount of gravy to serve with rice or mashed potatoes.  Everyone loved it.

text:
Good and easy!  I like to stay as close to the recipe as possible, but sometimes change is inevitable.  I didn't have the soup, so I made my own. Water, 2 beef bouillon cubes, and finely grated fresh onion (my family hates the texture of onion- so picky!).  Let come to a boil and thicken with cornstarch.  Worked great!  I didn't have bread crumbs, so I pulverized some saltines.  That did the trick.  Also didn't have mustard powder (I'm seeing a trip to the grocery store in the near future?) so I used a full teaspoon of prepared mustard.  Skipped the ketchup  because I know my family wouldn't like that flavor.  Used about a pound of meat and got four large steaks out of it.  Tripled up on the gravy and added sauteed sliced mushrooms to serve over garlic mashed potatoes.  Went over very well!  Thanks for the recipe!

I read reviews and changed the recipe a little. I used 1 package of Lipton dry onion soup mix. I mixed 1 tablespoon of the dry soup mix and 1/3 cup of water in the meat mixture. I browned the patties on the stove. I mixed the remainder of the onion soup mix with 1 cup of water and 1 can of cream of mushroom soup. I put the patties in a casserole dish and topped with gravy mixture. I baked in oven for 30 minutes. This was fantastic. I served with mashed potatoes. There was enough gravy for the patties and potatoes. This was very easy and quick to make.

text:
I'm giving this a five, because I took the advice of a reviewer back in January. As per the reviewer I used Lipton onion and mushroon soup mix instead of the canned onion soup(which I do not like). I flavored the patties like a cross between meatloaf and meatballs. I added worch. sauce and about two Tbs. of ketchup to the meat along with the egg, breadcrumbs and a half a packet of the soup mix. Prepared the gravy with the remaining packet and a half of the soup mix. Once the patties were browned I drained the fat and let the meat simmer with the gravy and added browned mushroons. This meal came together in about 30 minutes and hubby said I have to make it more often. Now I keep the soup mix on hand for a quick and yummy meal.

country:

text:
The recipe was great - I've always thought of Salisbury Steak as a tv dinner - not something I wanted to replicate at home. How wrong was I! Very tender & full of flavor. I did make a few changes - mostly as I wasn't able to fit all 6 patties in a skillet. Ingredients changed/added: I used a packet of French onion soup and added 12 oz. of water.; Italian breadcumbs in the patties, a package of fresh mushrooms, and a can of cream of mushroom soup. I browned the patties in a skillet and then transferred to a baking dish coated in cooking spray. I drained the grease from the skillet and added the mushrooms to the pan to brown a bit. I then added the ingredients as listed for the sauce with the addition of a can of cream of mushroom soup, whisked it all together, and let the sauce come up to a bubble. I poured it over the patties in the baking dish, covered with foil, and let the dish finish cooking in a 325 degree oven for 35-40 minutes.

country:

text:
This is now one of my favorite meals! I did do a few things differnt though. When making the patties I only used 1/2 can of the french onion soup because the first batch was a bit oniony & instead of bread crumps I used 1 cup of crushed ritz crackers. Using 1 cup helped the patties to stay together better. I browed the patties on both sides n then put them in a casserole dish. I then sauteed fresh mushrooms and sliced onions with real marsala wine in the same pan as I cooked the patties in and put them on top of the steaks. For the gravy I used the rest of the can of French Onion Soup, 1 can of cream of mushroom, 1 Tbl Worcesterhire, 1/2 tea mustard powder, a packet of lipton golden mushroom & onion soup and followed the directions for the gravy on the side & because of the strong onion tates I added a jar of Heinz Beef gravy. I poured everyhing on top of the patties and baked them in the oven at 350 for about 45 mins to an hr.

text:
Was a very good recipe, however I did change a few things.  In the hamburger mixture I used a package of dry onion soup mix, a squirt of ketchup, egg and 1/4 cup bread crumbs.  In the sauce mix I used a whole can of condensed french onion soup, half can of beef broth, 1 Tablespoon of cornstarch, squirt of ketchup instead of 1/4 cup, dash of worcestershire sauce, and I added some thyme and parsley.  However, next time I will omit the ketchup and the worcestershire.  It would be better with a pure beef taste instead of the vinegar in the ketchup and worcestershire.

Thank you Kelly for a great base recipe!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a super recipe! Very easy and quick. Great for a weeknight supper when you don't have much time. The patties cook up very quickly, and then while they simmer in gravy you can prepare a couple of simple side dishes. We loved it! This is also a perfect recipe for doubling: make twice as much, then put half in the freezer. It freezes very well, and when needed, you can just pull out of the freezer, heat, and serve. The recipe is also very forgiving: You don't have to measure everything exactly, just eyeball it. If you have any fresh herbs on hand, sprinkle a bit on top for garnish or stir into the gravy. Minced parsley or oregano work nicely. Paired with a heaping helping of mashed potatoes, this is just the ticket when you are in the mood for comfort food!

This turned out wonderful after making a few alterations - To the sauce mixture, I added a splash of red wine, a tablespoon of dijon mustard, disolved a buillion cube in ½ cup hot water and omitted the ketchup. Everyone loved these!  They all told me to make sure I give this a 5 =).  I have a habit of "tweaking" recipes to our liking and this was no exception.  I doubled the recipe and added some sausage to it as well.  After browning the patties, I added 1/2 cup of water to the pan and scraped up all the bits so it wouldn't be wasted and that liquid was added to the sauce (instead of plain h20).  I also doubled the sauce and added a can of cream of mushroom soup so we'd have more gravy and left the flour out since the soup thickened the sauce.  I then layered non-stick aluminum foil to a casserole dish and baked the patties covered in the sauce at 400 degrees for 30 minutes.  No dirty dishes for me!  Washed everything while patties were baking.  Thanks!

city:

country:
None
text:
How wonderful to run into this recipe here - I've been making this exact recipe for years!  Hand written recipe cards and recipe box received as a wedding present 9 years ago, this was the best one of the lot.  The card said it was a LA Times recipe.  Anyway,we eat this reguarly, I've given out the recipe several times over the years too.  For those who say they don't hold well or break up - I can't use the egg because my husband is allergic, so I make the patties thick and don't press them in the pan.  They only get moved when I turn them over.  And I put a lid on the pan for the 20 minutes - helps cook thick patties all the way through, plus keeps in moisture so you get more sauce, which is great over mashed potatoes!

text:
Thank you to the other reviewers for your helpful suggestions!  Like others, I tweaked this slightly and was very happy with the results.  I added one can of cream of mushroom soup and one can of low sodium beef broth to the gravy mixture.  I omitted the water and the ketchup.  I seared the patties in a frying pan and placed them in a foil-lined 9x13 baking dish.  I sauteed one 8 oz. container of sliced mushrooms in the frying pan after removing the patties, and then I added the cooked mushrooms to the gravy mixture.  I poured the gravy mixture over the patties and cooked them in the oven at 350 degrees for 30 minutes.  Delicious!

Delicious!  I used 2 lbs ground beef, 2 eggs and doubled the ingredients for the gravy.  After taking browned beef patties out of skillet I added 1/2 chopped onion to skillet before adding gravy.  Also when making gravy I added 1/2 cup of milk instead of beef bullion to make a creamier gravy and reduce salt.  I also did not add extra salt recipe calls for.  This recipe made 7 nice sized patties.  I made mashed potatoes & green beans to round out the dinner.  Will make again. Next time I will add mushrooms to gravy.  I think that will make it perfect.

text:
I'm only giving this 4 stars even though I changed the recipe quite a bit, I didn't like the ketchup in the recipe.  I doubled the gravy using one can of French onion and 1 can of golden mushroom soup, doubled all of the other gravy ingredients except the ketchup (I omitted the flour).  I followed another reviewer's suggestion and browned the patties on both sides then transferred them to a 13 x 9 pan and poured the gravy ingredients on top.  I also sliced one small yellow onion and put on top of the patties.  I covered the pan with foil and baked at 375 degrees for 45 minutes.  Next time I will substitute tomato sauce for the ketchup or leave it out completely.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
My review may not be entirely fair...I didn't have some important ingredients so I did what I could. I had one packet of dry onion soup. I put 2/3 of it in with the meat mixture and I also added about 1/2 tsp. of onion powder and garlic powder along with about 1/2 cup water and bread crumbs to the meat mixture. For the sauce I put the remaining onion soup mix, more onion and garlic powder, 1 1/2 tbl. of worschestire, 1/3 cup ketchup, heaping tblspn of flour and about 3/4 cup water. I didn't have mustard powder so I added about a tspn of dijon mustard. When I poured the sauce over the staeks it seemed thick so I added just a bit more water and let simmer for 20 min.....turned out amazing!!! My man said it was the best salisbury staek he's ever had and he's had ALOT of em'...maybe this review will help others out with some other options than the condensed soup that is called for. I think my method is also somewhat less fattening. I served with mashed potatos (soaks up the sauce) with corn and edmame. Thank you for sharing!

text:
Even a 39 yr old biker dad can make this excellent recipe. Family and I loved it.
I used 2-1/2 lbs ground beef mixed 1-1/2 packs liptons onion soup mix and other ingredients. I cheated with the gravy and used a jar of Heinz homestyle beef gray and another jar of mushroom gravy. I should have added one more jar of gravy though, gravy was a tad short when adding mashed taters to the meal. Used 2 eggs instead of one. Cut the ketchup down to a lil under a 1/4 cup. Had no mustard powder so used regular old liquid mustard. Garlic went nice in the gravy also. Also took advice of baking till brown in oven, worked great, and none fell apart. An A+ keeper. thanks for the tasty recipe.

text:
This was great and a keeper for sure! I did make several changes though...
Instead of browning the patties in a frying pan, I baked them in a 350 degree oven until they were browned. Then I drained any grease that was in the pan and poured the gravy over the patties and baked until the meat was done.  I did add ketchup but only added a dash, and chopped up some fresh mushrooms and added to the gravy.

I served with mashed potatoes and corn and it was a hit. Oh I also seasoned the meat a little more with some garlic powder and a little bit of dry onion soup mix. Thanx for the recipe we were more than pleased!

text:
I've made this for years, except I use cream of onion soup...add Worcestershire sauce and use prepared mustard (and very little catsup...too sweet).  I brown the outside of the patties quickly then finish baking in the oven and pour sauce over after meat is done.  'Shrooms are a good addition to the sauce as are thinly sliced onion.  Great on potatoes or rice.  I thin my sauce with water or milk to "stretch".

city:

country:

text:
I followed the recipe as given but after reading some of the reviews already posted, I decided to double the amount of sauce so I would have enough to pour over rice. Doubling the amount of sauce makes a lot more than you need, though. The sauce was interesting, but I did find it rather salty and would suggest not adding any extra salt (condensed onion soup is salty enough) and cutting back on the ketchup and worcestershire as well. The texture of the sauce is nice. I do think that salisbury steak should be served with a more traditional gravy-like sauce, as many reviewers have already noted. A good thing I found with this recipe is that the meat turned out to be very soft and tender as well as nicely flavored.

text:
I made this for last night's dinner, alongside mashed potatoes, wilted kale, and corn muffins. I made it pretty well close to the recipe, only leaving out the ketchup and subbing the French onion soup with the melee of partially-used onion/beefy onion mixes I had laying around.  Although I found myself wanting to add fresh garden herbs of some sort to brighten this up,  I resisted and added only fresh onion, garlic powder, and a can of mushrooms, which was excitedly pleading to be saved from culinary anonymity in the rear of the pantry. Topped with a few sprinkles of French's french fried onions and this was VERY good!  Very reminiscent of something my mother would have made back in the 70s/80s.  Very pleasing to my Texas taste buds.  I would love to share a picture, but not a morsel was leftover from any of the meal.  The potatoes played pillow to the beef, the cornbread made way with the gravy. The kale, usually a main attraction, got swept up in the forkwind as the obligatory price of admission required for the indulgence of traditional meat-and-potato dinners. By morning, only the not-so-non-stick muffin pan lay hungover in the sink to tell the tale.

text:
This is a family favorite, but like so many other reviewers, I made significant changes. I added garlic to the meat, used a can of mushrooms and cream of mushroom soup in the gravy, omitted the ketchup and mustard altogether.  I browned the parties first then transferred them to a casserole, covered them with the gravy, and baked it until the patties were done.

text:
I never liked the concept of salisbury steak. It grossed me out. This recipe changed my mind. I've now made it for my family of 4, and I've made it for a church dinner for 40 people. Super intense, addictive, crave inducing flavor. I think it's the worcestshire sauce that does the trick, plus the onion soup. At different cooking sessions I've subbed dried onion soup mix (reconstituted with water) when i didn't have canned french onion on hand, and i couldn't tell a difference in taste. I've also used the cream of mushroom substitution (instead of ketchup) for the gravy, and always doubled the gravy portions.. to.. well, get more gravy. We eat this until we want to burst, it's that yummy. Mashed potatoes and peas are my preferred sides. This is a keeper to impress anyone with 'home cooked gooodness'.

text:
I loved this one but did make two significant changes.  I omitted the ketchup and used beef stock in the meat mixture instead of the French onion soup...An excellent sauce can be made easily by using beef stock/broth, worchestershire sauce and adding corn starch (I used 1 1/2 cup stock, 1 TBSLP worchestershire, and a Tablespoon of cornstarch)  Mix well, and pour over meat.  I browned the meat patties and baked covered in oven at 350 for 30 minutes...If sauce isn't thick enough,  just uncover and bake uncovered for 5 or so minutes.  It was a delicious meal for us.

Display Name:
The Strut'N Mutt

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This one's earned a spot as a staple in our family's rotation.  My kids literally line up for first pick as soon as I turn stove off when I'm making it, so it's one of my absolute favorites  on AR.  My picky husband, who swore he would never touch Salisbury Steak before I made this one, absolutely loves this dish!  Only thing I do differently is saute 2 cloves of diced garlic with a medium chopped onion to add to the meat mixture before forming patties.  If patties stick when browning, a tiny shot of sherry or white wine to help deglaze the pan when flipping does the trick for me.  You'll also be able to scrape up any meat sticking to the bottom of the pan when you add the sauce, so don't get too fussy scraping with the spatula beforehand.  Also, flipping patties too early while browning will make them fall apart.  I've tried the original recipe as well as doubling sauce ingredients while keeping the ketchup qty the same.  In my house, doubling the sauce wins hands down.  Give this recipe a shot, it's a keeper!

Wonderful recipe!  I followed the ingredients for the mean patties to a tee.  I then browned them on both sides in vegetable oil in a frying pan.  Then transfered them to a foil lined baking dish.  I put a few slices of vidalia onion over the top as well as a can of sliced mushrooms.  I took the advice of another post and made gravy out of Lipton Beefy onion soup mix.  poured it over the top, coverd with foil and baked it at 350 for about 30 minutes!  rave reviews from the kids.  finally...a new idea for dinner with hamburger.

country:
None
text:
Like most reviewers, I tweaked mine a bit.  To the ground meat, I only added the egg, breadcrumbs, the salt and pepper, and about 1/3 of can of cream of mushroom soup.  I would use 1 more egg because it started to fall apart in the pan.  Then while it was browning, I doubled the gravy using 2 Dry onion soup mix packets, 4 cups water and the remaining mushroom soup.  I put the browned patties in a 9x13 dish and poured the gravy over and baked for 30 min. at 375 F.  It was delicious!  The boyfriend asked to add it to our normal rotation!

text:
This recipe is very good, and as others have said it tastes even better as leftovers the next day.  You really need to double the sauce, there simply isn't enough to pour over whatever starch you're serving it with.  I think this recipe is good as it is, salisbury steak is traditionally very simple and there's only a few ingredients here, so to me it's perfect as it is.  It makes me wonder why a lot of the other reviewers seem compelled to add ingredients such as powdered gravy mix, which is basically just salt and cornstarch, or mushroom soup, which has no business in salisbury steak.

text:
I changed this recipe based on what I had on hand @ the house: I used 1 tbsp of french onion soup mix (in 1 lb of ground chuck), 1/2 can of cream of mushroom, + the bread crumbs. Browned for 5 mins on each side. Mixed a mushroom gravy packet + 1 1/2 cans cream mushroom soup + milk and poured it over the browned meat and then baked. Yeah, i know i changed it a lot--but it's a great 'base' recipe that you can change up. AWESOME!

NEEDGREATRECIPES

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I used 1 pkg of ground turkey 85/15. I DID NOT use the egg,ketchup, water, worcesershire or mustard powder. What I did was made the patties as it is written in step 1 but without the egg. Then I used the remaining of french onion soup mixed with a half jar of brown gravy. To make it thick I made a paste out of 1 tbsp of flour and added a little water to the flour until it was moist and looked like paste. Then I stirred the flour paste in the gravy. Covered and cooked for about 20 minutes. Always add water to flour when you add it to a sauce, if you do not, then your sauce will have "flour balls" little balls of flour. This is a very easy recipe. We love it. I make it once a week at least. Thanks Kelly!!

text:
This was a hit!

My oldest son helped with dinner tonight, so we had a blast learning one of the basics together. I added half a diced onion to the meat mixture and a little ketchup/worchestershire. I thought what SLJ6 did was a good idea, only I layered a can of mushrooms I drained on the bottom of a 9x13 baking dish with the other half of onion I'd sliced, then sauteed. I then added the patties and poured the sauce over the top. I baked it at 350* for about a half hour. We all liked this. And for once, there were no leftovers. 

This recipe made six patties. 

If you make the gravy while the patties are cooking and let it sit, the flour that didn't incorporate into the gravy will dissolve.

text:
This is a very good basic recipe to start with. I tweaked it to our taste with the advice of those that went before.  I used 1/2 the catsup, doubled the sauce, and omitted the salt.  I used 1 pkg. dry onion soup mix, reconstituted, and added a 4 oz. can of mushrooms with juice to the sauce.  I made thinner steaks (6 per lb. of beef).  I also used 1 egg per lb. of beef and the patties stayed together nicely.

text:
I made this with only 1 lb. and made 4 steaks so I didn’t use the exact measurements but hubby wanted seconds so it was a hit. I only made minor changes using an envelope of onion soup mixed up with about 10 oz. water. I added a small can of mushrooms.  As others suggested I increased the gravy by adding some powdered gravy mix instead of the flour and 1 cup more water. I like sherry so I added some of that. I don’t like too much Worcestershire so I only added 1 tsp. I left out the ketchup entirely because so many reviewers complained about it and I didn’t think I’d care for it either. Like one reviewer said, don’t go crazy trying to make substitutions and changes per the reviews. This is a good recipe to approximate and juggle with what you have and what you like. If you are a fair cook it will always come out great.

I was out of eggs and milk to make mashed potatoes, so I improvised. I crumbled and cooked the ground beef, drained the fat, then added all the ingredients for the sauce, adding in some garlic powder. Then I added one cup of white rice and one cup of water, then simmered for 30 min. The end result was great!

Display Name:
MCCATHERN MOM

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I went with only 3 stars, but that doesn't mean this was a bad recipe. The beef patties were PERFECT; my husband raved about the texture and taste - true salisbury. However, the sauce left a lot to be desired in our opinions. I decided to double the sauce to go with the mashed potatoes & found the extra french onion soup too overwhelming. Also, my hubby is not a mustard fan at all, so its aroma in the sauce really stood out to him. Last, I would skip the ketchup entirely. Guess I'm too used to an oniony, beef gravy with salisbury steak & ketchup was not a pleasant surprise here. Since I was down to the wire when I discovered the final results of the recipe sauce, I simply removed the sauce from the simmered patties, whipped up 2 packs of Knorr brown gravy, added only the smallest amount of the first sauce to that, and served it up. Everyone was happy; even Mr. Picky Kid who, based on school cafeteria salisbury steak, thought that it was going to be awful.
I will definitely use the recipe for the patties again, but will have to tinker with the sauce. Maybe... the rest of the french onion soup, with Knorr beef boullion broth, flour to thicken, and a splash of worchestershire. Sounds tasty already!

text:
Based on other reviews, we made several changes that worked out great.  We halved the recipe, but for the sauce we used the original amounts.  For the onion soup, we substituted 10.75 oz condensed cream of mushroom soup mixed with 1 oz dry onion soup mix.  We also added some extra water because it was very thick, and 8 oz of canned mushrooms.  We also made the patties half the size called for, to allow everyone to have the serving size they wanted, and to make sure the meat cooked all the way through.  The flavor was terrific, and the sauce made a wonderful gravy for mashed potatoes.  Great for a cold winter day!

text:
AWESOME!  My husband has been raving for two days about this one!  I agree totally!  My kids ate without comment, which is a very good sign that they enjoy something! I didn't have any condensed onion soup, so I substituted cream of mushroom soup mixed with Lipton instant onion soup mix. (Added one third of this mix to the meat mixture, and the remainder went toward the end result of the gravy) I decreased the ketchup, but increased the worcestershire, breadcrumbs, and added more water/flour mixture to the gravy.  I used Gravy Master to darken the gravy as well.  I prepared this in my electric skillet, and it turned out fantastically.  Served over mashed potatoes w/ broccoli on the side.  This is a keeper!

We just had this for dinner and thought it was delicious.  Something to remember when handling ground beef is to not press it alot.  Just form the patties as described and I think you will be pleased as they stay moist, absorb liquid from the sauce and are very tender.  The gravy was tasty and this made a quick fall meal with broasted potatoes, fried cabbage and applesauce.  Thanks!!!

i made this recipe at first for family they raved for it......made it for sick friend.........she asked for the recipe.....then neighbor came and asked for it even my mother who lives in nevada raved about it .....ok heres the thing i modified it...i added 1/4 cup of chopped onion to meat mixture i used 2 cups of lipton onion soup mix instead of french onion soup mix i also added nature seasoning,minced garlic to meat..made gravy mix and added a can of cream of mushroom soup with 1/4 can of water simmered with the patties..it is absolutely wonderful with egg noodles i also added fresh sliced mushrooms to gravy

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
After trying one night for dinner, we made this as the beef dish for a party of 70. Using 25 lbs of beef and increasing the recipe proportionately (omitting added salt).  Added mushrooms.  We made the patties, cooled them overnight and brought out to room temperature.  Grilled at 550 on each side just to place char marks.  Cooled on metal sheets, placed into heat sealed vacuum bags single level.  Froze until morning of party...seven days later.  

Using sous vide, finished at 137 for three and a half hours.  Meanwhile, made sauce adding mushrooms.  After simmering,  layered sauce and Salisbury steaks into a large chaffing dish with 25% heat so they would just stay warm.  

Out of 130, there was almost none left.  With other foods, this entree was listed as top next to my wife's mashed potatoes.  Will we make this again?  Oh yea...maybe substituting half the ground beef with venison.

text:
This recipe is delicious, but it isn't what you would really expect from salisbury steak.  For one thing, if you want enough gravy left over for mashed potatoes, double the gravy.  I didn't because I was serving with baked potatoes and the amount of gravy was just right for the steaks themselves.  For another thing, this recipe is a little on the sweet side because of the ketchup.  I thought it tasted good, but it's not really traditional and may not be your cup of tea.

Apparently, the ratings are all based on the cooks personal alterations, which I believe is an extremely misleading way to rate a recipe. I cooked this in a huge hurry not reading the reviews like I usually do, thinking "great, this looks like a fantastic recipe, lots of stars I think I'll try it" But no, I feel terrible for feeding this to my family. I am very upset with myself for trying this recipe, I wasted a perfectly good pound and a half of meat that I could have put to much better use. Dog food, perhaps.

None
text:
I had a severe attack of gout and have had to adapt a number of great recipes from AR. If you are prone to gout, broths and soups made with beef or chicken broth are one of the worst things you can eat. I was so hungry for this Salisbury Steak that I had to find something to sub for the canned onion soup. So I caramelized two very large yellow onions, which made a little over a cup, then I put them in a small saucepan with about a cup and a half of vegetable broth and gently warmed that and let it cool. I then followed the recipe as written, except using my homemade onion soup concentrate in place of the canned. It turned out fabulous and tasted exactly the same: Delicious.

I have an 8 year son that likes to help me cook and we were looking for something to make with the ground sirloin we just bought and this sounded and looked good. text:
Perfect as written but the second and third time I made it I added fresh garlic and 8 ounces of fresh sliced mushrooms with onions, added chopped fresh parsley in meat mixture, added more seasoning such as oregano just for more flavor.  Tripled the recipe for meat mixture as I always do for my big eatin family.  Quadrupled the gravy and probably added more sherry (the real stuff) as it MAKES THE DISH! Do NOT skip the SHERRY, it's a MUST. Also, I never use flour to thicken gravy, I used cornstarch in place of flour (1 TBS.Cornstarch to 2 TBS.Flour Better flavor and no lumps. Even though I quadrupled the gravy, I only used approx. 4 TBS. Of cornstarch sprinkled over onion/mushroom/garlic mixture. Served with mashed potatoes (A MUST) and fresh spinach.  My family from ages 9 to 55 LOVE this recipe.  THANK YOU SO MUCH for such a simple, comforting, recipe. Last time I made this dish, I added a can of Golden Mushroom soup to replace some of the beef broth (as I hate to do!!!) but I have to admit it tasted really good as well.  Everything else the same. ENJOY~!

I loved this, and it was a huge hit with the family! I did add a can of cream of mushroom soup to the gravy and im glad i did because i think the ketchup would have otherwise been overwhelming.  i cooked the steaks in a cast iron skillet and baked in the oven for 30 minutes after adding the gravy. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/269431.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this twice, once as written & then with improvements. As written, the sauce was not good. Way too tangy & thin. The patties completly fell apart when trying to cook in fry pan. I read all the reviews and improved by: adding 1/2 pack of onion soup mix to ground beef mix, along with worchestire sauce & garlic powder. The just browning the patties in a fry on over high heat & transferring to casserole pan. Make sure to use lean cut of meat, or you'll have a greasy mess. I used same fry pan to make gravy, scrapping leftovers to infuse flavor. Adding about 1/2 cup beef broth, remaining onion soup mix, mustard, ketchup, and a touch of brown sugar. I didn't like the color, so I added a bit of jarred brown gravy to it, this gave that traditional color. While mking the gravy, I sauteed mushrooms and added those to the gravy. Poured over patties and baked 375 45 mins.

text:
Outstanding.  I made changes similar to other reviewers: Omit the salt, ketchup, and mustard; use corn starch instead of flour as needed; to the meat mixture add the Worcestershire sauce and a finely chopped, sauteed onion (medium); for the gravy, add the remaining onion soup, a can of cream of mushroom soup, and a half-packet of dry onion soup mix, and heat it all through on the stove top.  After browning the patties, place them in a foil-lined dish and pour the gravy over them, and bake covered in the oven for 45 minutes at 375.  Make at least double the gravy.  My family raved.

country:
None
text:
I wanted to use 2 lbs. of ground beef and stretch this a bit, so I added an extra egg, an envelope of Lipton onion soup mix, and a few extra tablespoons of bread crumbs to the meat mixture. The steaks were wonderful -- tender and flavorful. The sauce nearly ruined this for me; the ketchup and worcestershire were just out of place with salisbury steak, way too tangy. I had to add 2 jars of Heinz brown gravy and a can of cream of mushroom soup to tone the sauce down enough to eat it. Next time I'll leave out the ketchup, worcestershire and possibly the mustard, and stick with a standard mushroom-onion gravy. Oh -- and to whoever suggested baking this covered in the oven rather than finishing it on the stovetop, thanks! Much easier to finish it in the oven so you can work on the rest of the meal while it's cooking. Wonderful recipe for the actual beef patties, but if you're looking for the taste of traditional salisbury steak, I suggest using a more traditional gravy recipe.

Display Name:
jbcevans

text:
It is a great recipe! Especially for first timers like me :) I rated it 4 stars b/c i read a lot of the reviews & made quite a few changes based off that. I didn't feel i could give it 5 stars since i didn't do the original recipe first. I added 1/3 of Lipton Onion Soup mix to the hamburger meat , along with a squirt of Dijon mustard, and a tbsp of all purpose flour w/ the other required ingredients. I also cooked the meat in a little olive oil about half way done. With the gravy, i went with a couple different reviews and decided to do my own thing. I used 2 brown gravy pkgs and started adding ingredients as i went. I did the recommended amount of water on pkg. I added a can of cream of mushroom soup, the rest of the Lipton Onion Soup mixture, sliced mushrooms, sliced onions, and a squirt of Dijon mustard. I only put about half the recommended about of ketchup; no flour and and salt and peppered to my liking. Poured it on top the meat after pouring out the grease. And let it simmer for about 20 mins, stirring often. My husband loved it!!! I thought it was great!! For a first time and kind of doing my own thing, it turned out great. But if you don't like a really onion taste, then leave out the sliced onions. I will definitely be doing this again. Thanks for the recipe and suggestions!!

text:
this is one of the few things I can actually say that both my husband and I loved and will definitely make again, Even though I didn't follow the recipe exactly I still got what I needed from other reviews so might as well still rate this 5 stars!  I added minced garlic to the meat mixture.   I didnt use the worcestershire sauce or ketchup for the sauce, instead I used the  added cream of mushroom and packet of brown gravy mix and half a cup of water to the remaining french onion soup.  After browning the patties in the skillet I put them in a glass baking dish, covered with the sauce and baked them in the oven at 375 for 30 minutes.  Delicious!!

text:
I had a hard time with these for some reason.  I didnt have a pan big enough to fit all 6 patties, so i split it up.. I ended up burning the bottoms of the fist batch of patties. I dont think i had enough sauce in the fist batch, so i maxed another can of French Onion soup and other ingredients and the 2nd batch was much better.. *Make sure you have enough sauce in the pan with the patties to avoid burning, the 2nd batch ended up being pretty good :) the extra sauce was used to pour on top of the meat and potatoes. Also, remember that the patties shrink up a lot when you cook them.  Make them bigger is you dont want them to shrink up into little minis.

text:
Made this for dinner last night for the first time.  It was VERY good.  But, I believe the recipe is off with respect to how much gravy should be made with the beef.  I made 2 lb's of beef, and used double the gravy ingredients and still thought it could have used more.  Also, the recipe says to stir.  I tried that and the patties fell apart, so just don't cook on too high of heat, then when you are getting the gravy out, scrape the bottom of the pan.  It's really good.

Quick and Easy.  I made a few changes, some by accident, some on purpose.  The accident was that I just went down the list and started adding, so the ingredients at the end that were for the gravy, went into the meat mixture.  Oops, my bad.  So I added more ketchup and wor. to the gravy.  I think I also added onion and garlic powder to the meat, but I did not add any soup.  (but remember I added ketchup and wor. sauce?  so that gave me the moisture I needed)  I used c.of mushroom soup instead, and I added french fried onions to the soup mix.   It was very quick and easy and had a good flavor.  Thanks for sharing.

This was a very good salisbury steak. I made this per the recipe and was pleased with the results. A very good flavor overall. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is sooo yummy!  But I had to alter the recipe a little.  I didn't have the condensed soup so used the Lipton Onion Soup Mix instead.  I added a cup of water with the soup mix.  When I started cooking steaks in the sauce, I realized the sauce was too thick.  I also figured out that the sauce will be completely gone if I cook the meat for 20 min.  So, I added another envelope of the soup mix combined with a cup of water.  Then I added 1/4 cup water, 1/2 tsp dry mustard, 1.5 Tbsp kechup.  I omitted salt completely.  The consistancy and amount of the gravy was just perfect.

text:
Very good.  I mixed the meat just like the recipe here calls for, and pan fried them on both sides til good and brown.  But for the gravy part I used the recipe on the side of the lipton onion soup mix box, poured it over top of the oval patties, baked at 375 for about 30 minutes.  Served with mashed potatoes, green beans, and corn....wonderful!!!  The meat was so tender, but yet not falling apart, and the gravy was excellent.  Hint....I used part of the condensed soup from the can as part of the water needed for the lipton onion soup gravy.  It's a keeper, as a matter of fact I am fixing it for the second time in as many weeks.  My family loved them.

country:
None
text:
First time trying Salisbury steak and both my boyfriend and I really liked it! It's similar to meatloaf but saucier. I decided to mix 1/3 cup of the soup, bread crumbs, egg, S&P prior to mixing in the ground beef since overhandling meat tends to lead to toughness. I added about 2 pinches of salt, but I think I will omit all together next time since I thought the final product was a tad too salty. I also added 1/4 of diced onion sauteed prior to browning the patties. I noticed that it was a little too tangy for me so I added 1 tbsp of brown sugar. I served with leftover scalloped potatoes and corn. Will make again!

text:
This was delicious.  I basically did what another reviewer (CAJUNWIFE123) did, and it turned out great.  I added a can of Golden mushroom soup, a little brown gravy powder, a little more of the water, worstershire sauce (I did a full two lbs of ground beef), etc.  Browned the patties, then put them in a greased 9x13, covered with the gravy, then covered with foil, and baked at 400 for 35 minutes. It was great, and the hubby raved!  I even got my 2 and 4 year olds to take a few bites, and that's saying something.  I did the extra gravy for two reasons...I was doing more beef, and I like gravy on my mashed potatoes.  It made a lot that way, but it was great!  Great recipe, thanks so much!  This was my first time making salisbury steak, and I'd say it was a success.

text:
This was wonderful!  The things I did different are,  I used two pounds of ground beef, two cans of French onion soup ½ in meat the rest in gravy, I put ¾ bag of Lipton French onion soup in meat and the rest with one more bag in the gravy, 3 T flour and will use 4 next time, and beef stock (about 25 oz).  We like lots of gravy in our house.  I put the meat on the grill and cooked 75% to get the flavor from the grill.  I them put them in the gravy to let them simmer.  Do not put in any salt it will get plenty from the other ingredients.  I used more bread crumbs not sure how much but keep adding until it doesn't stick to clean dry hands.  Other than that I followed the recipe.

text:
I only gave this recipe 4 stars because the steaks are GREAT but the sauce was horrible. As soon as I started cooking the sauce with the patties, they started smelling like fast-food burgers instead of Salisbury steak, so I quickly rescued the steaks and made the sauce with ONLY french onion soup and flour. I'm glad I did! I should learn not to trust recipes with ketchup, because I don't like it, and the flavor/smell of the ketchup was overbearing. There was still a small hint of it even with the little bit that remained on the steaks after I rescued them from this potential disaster. My husband, who doesn't care for Salisbury steak, said "I didn't know Salisbury steak could taste so good!" and he kept sneaking bites of the leftovers! This recipe is a keeper, with the change that I made. It really hits the spot.

My hubby loved this dish!! Winner Winner yummy dinner:) I did slice 2 onions and 2 pkgs of fresh mushrooms, sauteed these up. I added 2 tomato paste after they were soft and added beef bouillon. I made a slurry of corn starch and water, I used this to thicken the sauce. I mixed Lipton onion soup, Worcestershire sauce and cracker crumbs to the ground beef and brown off the patties. Everyone jumped into the mushroom hot tub and simmered for 15 mins. Really easy and oh soo good! I served them over mashed tators. Thank You Kelly!! I will use this recipe again and again now that I know how quick it was.

I made this for my picky family and once they took one look at it they wouldn't even try it! I used 93% hamburg and I used Pam to fry the steak then I poured over the gravy and put it all in the oven for about 20 minutes until the gravy was hot. Served on mashed potatoes. text:
My whole family loved it! This is what I call comfort food. I did not have any problems at all with my patties crumbling or falling apart.  I made sure they got a good sear before I flipped them over and they stayed together just fine.  I used ground sirloin and these were still very moist and tender.  Followed recipe with the exceptions for doubling the gravy and adding a can of cream of mushroom soup to the gravy, put patties and gravy in a covered baking dish with gravy at 350 for 1 hour.  Came out very very moist and tender. Will definitely be making this again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
DON'T CHANGE A THING...just the shape of it. So much easier to prep and cook and no frying.
I have made this recipe a few times but as a baked meatloaf instead of fried individual patties.  I mix the meat as directed, place it in a Pam-greased pyrex loaf dish, turn it upside down after running a butter knife around the edges of the pyrex dish and let the meat fall out on the center of a cookie sheet covered with parchment paper and bake it at 350 for around 1 hour. I place the other ingredients in a small pan and simmer it for a little while. Then I pour the "gravy" over the meatloaf. Fabulous.  The key is the french onion soup so do not eliminate it.  Bon Appétit!

This was great comfort food. I had to modify a little bit, as I didn't think French Onion Soup would fly with our tastebuds, so I used Golden Mushroom Soup instead. I did add a can of mushrooms and doubled the gravy ingredients (except for the ketchup, I probably only used 1/8 cup total). The patties did fall apart a bit on me, but oh well! I took other's advice of browning them and then baking in the oven. Baked at 375 for 30 minutes which was perfect. Served with mashed potatoes and garlic green beans... perfect comfort food. :)

text:
This rating is based on other reviewers changes. 
Absolutely delicious! I omitted the ketchup, added a can of cream of mushroom, a Lipton onion soup packet and doubled the sauce for my garlic mashed potatoes. I used italian bread crumbs because that's all I had on hand.
It was very oniony which we loved. I browned it in the skillet and placed in a foil lined casserole dish, drizzled with sauce and covered with foil. Baked at 400 for about 25-30 min.
It came out absolutely perfect! My entire family enjoyed it. Even my picky 7 year old daughter. My husband told me to keep the recipe forever.

This was pretty good. It's nothing to write home about, but what do you expect from salisbury steak? I halved this recipe (made this for my fiance and I), but otherwise, followed Kelly's directions to the letter. I had a difficult time keeping my patties from crumbling, but found that, if turned minimally (and carefully), they were fine. Served with carrots/peas, mashed potatoes and the rest of the sauce (for topping the potatoes - yum!). This is a fine recipe for salisbury steak, but not somehting that I'd make on a routine basis (but I will make on occasion), although, I'm sure kids would gobble this up (but I don't have any...). Thanks for sharing, Kelly!

text:
haven't had salisbury steak for a looooooong time - since high school!  i would have taken a photo of this dish but we always gobble it up too fast!  this recipe was very simple to put together and is quite tasty - have made 2 times already!  i always keep dry onion soup on hand and so i will try w/that the next time i make it because i always have to go out and buy the canned condensed soup.  i will also try to make more sauce as the family loves it over everything!  thank you very much for sharing your recipe!
update:  2/08 have made this recipe a number of times.  had to double today because hubby never gets to taste more than one leftover pattie hint:  if your patties are falling apart...you need to remember NOT to dump the whole can of soup in w/the raw hamburger like i did the first couple of times i made this dish.  the recipe is PERFECT.  you can even put in a large baking pan, cover w/foil and bake at 350 in oven for around 30-45 minutes.  update:  10/08 we're having this again (double recipe) i fry in large skillet and then stand oval patties upright in dutch oven over low heat; cover and simmer for 20-30 minutes. serving w/garlic mash and mixed frozen veggies.

Where on Earth has this been all my life! Rainy day diner dinners of my childhood are leaping to life and I am overjoyed. 
I didn't really even fiddle with this recipe. I did add a little garlic powder to the patties and I sauteed a few mushrooms in the pan before I added the gravy and used a teenie bit of brandy to deglaze the pan, but man, am I impressed. I feel like a sweaty old guy in a white t-shirt and greasy apron made this for me. My only note is to use a non-stick skillet!

I doubled the sauce as others had suggested, no change in the recipe and finished in the oven.  We were very dissappointed.  The steaks were tender however the sauce was so overpowering and tasted of too much worcestershire and concentrated onion soup.  I think it would be better with half onion soup and half beef broth to tame it some and perhaps a bit less worcestershire.  With a few changes I think this could be very good. Perhaps reconstituting the onion soup would help.

text:
I made some changes as I saw others did as well. Instead of using condensed soup I used dry onion soup mix instead. For the sauce I used dry mushroom and onion soup mix. I seared the patties first then transfered them to the oven at 350 for 30 min. After they were cooked I then poured the sauce over the patties. I served this with green beans, mashed potatoes and bisquits. This made a great meal and I will make this again.

text:
This was excellent! Even the picky teenager ate it! Like a previous reviewer, I added a can of cream of mushroom soup and the dry onion soup mix but I like a lot of gravy so I also added two cups of water with a large beef bouillon cube desolved and a jar of mushrooms. I used crushed butter crackers instead of bread crumbs and added 1/4 teaspoon poultry seasoning to the beef mixture. I trippled the flour since I added more liquid so the sauce was nice and thick. Served over noodles. This will be a keeper in our house. Thanks

I don't know if I should review this recipe, considering I made a lot of adjustments, but here goes: I didn't have french onion soup, so I used Cream of Mushroom. Didn't have bread crumbs, so I used Cracker Crumbs. Skipped the ketchup & mustard (as suggested by other reviewers), & went easy on the worcestershire & salt.  I used (2) instant beef gravy packets (followed the directions) and poured on top of the cooked patties & added additional mushrooms to the gravy. This recipes was super easy & tasty, & seems quite suitable for altering to personal taste or pantry availability.  Will definately cook again.

text:
I took the advice from other members, and used changes given my another member. She altered the recipe and I really enjoyed her version. Her changes are as follows.."I used Lipton Onion Mushroom soup & dip mix. I used half an envelope to the meat mixture as well as 1/3 cup Italian-style breadcrumbs, 2 Tbsp. of the canned french onion soup, 1 tsp. worcestershire sauce, 1/4 tsp. dry mustard, and the original 1/8 tsp. ground black pepper, I also omitted the salt. I only used 1 lb. of ground beef, which made 4 patties. For the gravy, I used the rest of the soup, the rest of the first envelope plus the other in the box of the Onion Mushroom soup & dip mix, 1 1/4 cup of water, 1 Tbsp. ketchup, 1 Tbsp. worcestershire sauce, 1/2 tsp. dry mustard, and 1 small can of sliced mushrooms, drained. The gravy turned out the right thickness so I never had to add flour or cornstarch. 

Thank you both for your suggestions, I will be making this again.

city:

region:

country:

text:
I gave this 3 stars for the original recipe, but 5 for the alterations suggested by others. I switched it up a bit as well. I couldn't find Lipton onion soup mix, so instead I used Lipton Onion Mushroom soup & dip mix. I used half an envelope to the meat mixture as well as 1/3 cup Italian-style breadcrumbs, 2 Tbsp. of the canned french onion soup, 1 tsp. worcestershire sauce, 1/4 tsp. dry mustard, and the original 1/8 tsp. ground black pepper, I also omitted the salt. I only used 1 lb. of ground beef, which made 4 patties. For the gravy, I used the rest of the soup, the rest of the first envelope plus the other in the box of the Onion Mushroom soup & dip mix, 1 1/4 cup of water, 1 Tbsp. ketchup, 1 Tbsp. worcestershire sauce, 1/2 tsp. dry mustard, and 1 small can of sliced mushrooms, drained.  The gravy turned out the right thickness so I never had to add flour or cornstarch. My Husband loved this and said it was better than any he has ever had. Thanks for the suggestions.

text:
Yum! Yum! Yum! I didn't even have to ask my husband first what he thought. He volunteered after the first bite how great the food was! (This hardly ever happens around here.) I followed the instructions exactly...except all I had was Progresso brand French Onion Soup (not concentrate). So, I put mostly onions and very little water into the meat, drained a little of the liquid for the sauce, and added some extra flour to make sure to compensate for the liquid. Totally wonderful. Thanks for submitting it. We will be making this again and again!

Oh, and by the way, I cooked them in the pot, not the oven. I didn't have a bit of trouble with them falling apart. Just make sure they are not too thin.

Enjoy!

I have made this many times over the past 4 years.  As I am trying to stay away from processed foods, I don’t use the onion soup, So I put diced onion in the burger mixture.  I only use 1 lb of lean ground beef....  Also, I slice a medium onion and use 8 oz of sliced baby Bella mushrooms, these added after I turn the patties over. All other ingredients are as the recipe calls for, except I use potato starch instead of flour.

text:
I will give the taste a five but I had to give the recipe a two because the ingredients doesn't give enough for the gravy. Normally the salisbury sides are mashed potatoes or white rice. You're supposed to have enough gravy for the mashed potatoes or rice as well as the salisbury itself. This recipe and ingredients did not.My recommendation if you want gravy as well to add an additional can of condensed French Onion Soup or even two additional cans for good measure.

The only change I made was substituting Worcestershire sauce for A-1 and soy sauce because I didn't have any on hand.  I don't like the cream of mushroom method, but I would use a little of real or jar mushroom if I felt like it.  The steaks turned out great and better than I expected.  I'm glad they weren't hard. I'll make this again sometime.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves these steaks!   I browned the steaks on the stove top. Then I sauteed some fresh mushrooms and a little bit of onion because we like those in our gravy (and they're in the picture but not the recipe??). I followed other reviewers' advice and added a can of cream of mushroom soup to the condensed French onion soup both to thicken it up and make more gravy to serve with the mashed potatoes I made on the side. I put all ingredients in a 9x13 pan covered in the oven at 400 degrees for 30 minutes.   I'm not sure I would add the ketchup next time.
NOTE to self: My family devours these - double the recipe!

text:
I Made this Slow Cooker Salisbury Steak last Sunday, exactly as the recipe shows. I added 1 small jar of sliced mushrooms, (about an hour before it was finished cooking) at the request of my hubby. I Made homemade mashed potatoes and green beans as a side, and it got rave reviews from everyone at the dinner table! There really isn't much 'cooking' to this meal, which I love! I'll admit I was a little skeptical when I saw that a beef dinner called for 2 cans of cream of chicken soup, But WOW, what a FABULOUS meal it turned out to be! The gravy turns a nice dark brown shade during cooking, just like the photo, and it is so full of beefy flavor, without being too salty! The gravy was delicious on the meat, and especially as a topping on the potatoes too!This was a very Easy recipe to put together, you basically just brown the meat, stir the ingredients and put it all in the crock pot. I used my hamburger press when I shaped the patties for browning, which helped to keep them all a nice uniform size. I wound up with 10 Salisbury steaks Appx 4" round. This meal fed 4 adults and 2 kids, with leftovers,  which were eaten for lunch the next day, and it  tasted twice as good!  The meat held together perfectly, even after cooking in the crock pot which made it easy to transfer to a serving dish at dinner time. This was the Perfect family meal for a chilly Sunday in winter. It's a Wonderful 'Comfort Food' recipe, and My kids have even asked me twice this week if I'll make those 'gravy b

text:
Rating this recipe how it is, I give it four stars. With a few modifcations I'm in LOVE. For the gravy, I use the rest of the french onion soup can, a can of cream of mushroom soup, a bit of brown gravy mix to thicken it up, the mustard powder, and worchestershire sauce. Its delish. I also put a bit of minced garlic in the meat mixture, as well as lawry's seasoned salt and garlic powder. I brown the patties first and then cover them in the gravy in a baking pan, and cook for 30 minutes at 400 degrees. Pretty amazing.

text:
11/17/17 - I made this a second time, finally! I used the condensed French Onion soup this time and added more bread crumbs to the patties. They held together a lot more easily this time around. I also loaded it down with lots of sliced onions that I sauteed in the ground beef grease from frying the patties beforehand.  
8/6/14 - My family and I thoroughly enjoyed this recipe. I did not have any condensed French Onion soup on hand, so instead I mixed together a pack of dry onion soup mix with a can of cream of mushroom and chicken soup. So glad I did this - the patties were mushy as it was (I can't imagine them staying together if I'd have used the soup it called for.) I made the patties *in* the pan as they cooked, I'd put in a spoonful at a time until it all stuck together. The sauce itself was delicious. I'd never had Salisbury steak before but my husband said this tasted close to the one he had as a child. Next time, I may tweak a little but great recipe. I'll definitely fix it again :)

Display Name:
Leann Tucek

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2518250.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Okay, I made this for the first time a couple weeks ago and followed the recipe except I only used one tablespoon of ketchup.  The flavor wasn't anything special and there was not much gravy.  I rated this from the first time I made it because it was closest to the recipe.  The second time I made it I took morgmoms advice and used 1 packet of French onion soup mix (Lipton).  Half the packet I used in the meat mixture and half I used for the gravy.  I omitted the canned soup completely.  For the patties I also added about a teaspoon of Worcestershire sauce, 2 tablespoons of milk omitted the salt and used eggs and breadcrumbs, of course.  For the gravy, first I sautéed onions and mushrooms in 3 tablespoons of butter.  Then I added 3 tablespoons of flour and the rest of the onion soup mix, and mixed that up for a minute or so.  Finally I added 1 cup of beef STOCK, not broth and 1 cup of water.  This was the best salisbury steak I ever made!  I am going to submit this to allrecipes, although it takes them forever to review and post it.

It fixed the recipe as written except I doubled the gravy as others recommended since we are gravy folks, but kept the ketchup at 1/4 c. I thought the steak itself was perfect, so tasty, but I wasn't a huge fan of the gravy from the ketchup standpoint. It was still too twangy I thought. Really good enough to make again, but next time I think I'll tweak the ketchup down to 1/8 c and try that. It's still not a basic onion soup gravy flavor totally but I don't want a tomato flavor in this dish. Was really super over rice.

Should be 5 stars! BUT they pictured mushrooms in the sauce, which is missing. I sautéed 8 oz. of mushrooms with 1 tsp of butter and 1 tsp of olive oil. Doubled the amount of sauce and added the sautéed mushroom. After the initial browning I added the sauce to the pan. Covered and placed in a 350 degree oven for 40 minutes. This is another keeper recipe for the books. Even my 4 yr old grandson liked it! Thank you Kelly Berenger!

I have used this recipe a number of times & enjoyed it each & every time. text:
This was a winner in my house. Like most people, I changed the origional recipe, the second time around also. I added a pinch of garlic to my meat mixture and used a can of cream of mushroom soup. My wife doesnt like mushrooms so the soup idea works well because their so small she doesnt even notice that they are in there. To give the meat a little extra eye appeal, I used my G. Forman Grill to cook the meat. Nice sear marks on the meat and no grease to deal with. I like my meat a little on the spicier side so I used Chineese Mustard for a little extra kick. It was too the nine's anyway you make it! Depending on our mood, we will serve it over mashed potatoes, rice or wide egg noodles. We love gravy so we doubled that part of the recipe. Leftovers are the bomb! YUMMY

text:
Followed recipe alterations from other reviewers. Omitted the salt. ADDED INGREDIENTS: can of cream of mushroom soup, mixed 1 envelope of onion soup mix, sauteed 1/2 onion sliced, sliced baby portobello mushrooms w/ sauce.

Browned 6 patties on top of stove. Finished in oven, 375 degrees, transferred patties to large casserole dish, poured sauce mix over patties, covered w/ aluminum foil. Cooked for 25 min. Removed foil, cooked for additional 5 minutes. Removed from oven and voila.....Super Delish!!!! Taste like recipe took hours. Served w/ garlic mashed potatoes and steamed veggie mix.

text:
Good recipe.  After reading reviews, I added some dry onion soup mix to the beef, and doubled the sauce minus the ketchup; also, I didn't have any dried mustard so substituted some Dijon mustard in there.  I browned the steak patties (they stayed together pretty well for me) and then put them in a foil covered casserole dish and poured the sauce/gravy over it.  Covered and baked at 375 degrees F for about half an hour or so.  Good and moist, but again, the patties keep together really well.

Display Name:
imseansmom

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4554616.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love, love, love this recipe with modifications as mentioned by some other people.  I used 2 cans of French Onion soup, 1 3/4# ground beef, 3/4c bread crumbs, 1 1/2T flour, 1/2 cup water, 2T Worcestershire sauce, 1 pkg. dry onion soup mix, and omitted the salt and ketchup.  I also added about a tsp of garlic powder to the meat and browned it with 3 slices of bacon to add a little flavor.

I was looking for something to put in the crock pot, so I only browned both sides of the patties in the skillet, transferred them to the crock pot, poured the sauce over the patties, and cooked on low for about 4-5 hours.

Made these for a couple of hungry guys after a hard days work and it all disappeared!  Was glad I doubled the recipe for the gravy, because we served it over garlic masshed potatoes. Yum yum!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thanks for the recipe and suggestions :) It was DELICIOUS. For the patties, I added garlic powder with the salt, black pepper, and dried onion flakes and 2tsp. mayo ( instead of 1 egg ) then mixed in the bread crumbs and formed them into oval patties. I browned them in a nonstick skillet on both sides then placed them in a dinner plate with raised sides. Then I poured some gravy on the steak patties. For the gravy, I mixed together 1 can ( 10.5 ounce ) cream of mushroom soup, 1 jar of Heinz mushroom brown gravy and 1/4 can of water. I mixed the sauce until simmering then poured some brown gravy on garlic mashed potatoes and served with steamed, buttered broccolli florets. Yum! :D

text:
This was surprisingly easy and delicious! I could not find condensed onion soup so I used Campbell's French Onion Soup instead. I still stuck to the 1/3 cup in the meat mixture and for the sauce on top I used another 1/3 cup of soup I only used 1/8 cup water rather than 1/4 because the soup was not condensed. At all points in the cooking process it either looked disgusting or smelled hideous so I was a little nervous what the end product would be. However, the patties were absolutely delicious! Melted right in your mouth. The recipe cook times are spot on, no adjustment needed. I would maybe add some sauteed onions and mushrooms next time for presentation. Definitely making this again, my family wanted seconds and even thirds!

Rating:
5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe. To be fair, I do not follow the recipe exactly, rather I've changed it up thanks to the reviews.  I add 1/3 can of cream of mushroom soup to the ground beef mixture along with seasoned salt, breadcrumbs, diced onions and some diced garlic.  

I also do not make the gravy as written in this recipe, I just make two packets of lipton onion and mushroom soup mix as the gravy, following the directions on the side of the box.  After browning the patties in the skillet, I transfer to a casserole dish, pour sauce over the top and bake in the oven for about 30 minutes.  Comes out sooooo moist and delish, it's indescribable! We eat with mashed potatoes and sister shubert rolls. MMMMM.

This was very, very good.  I was surprised at how moist the meat turned out.  Just a side note, I have made this according to recipe posted, and also tweaked a bit, and both are great.  If you like a more onion salty meat, you can add a packet of onion soup mix and cream of mushroom soup to the gravy and its wonderful.  Sometimes I only use 1/2 packet of the onion soup because hubby doesnt like alot of salt...if i do it this way I dont add any salt to the hamburger meat.  Dont forget to add fresh mushrooms to gravy if you like them!

None
text:
SO TASTY!  We have food allergies at our house, so I omit the egg and use homemade bread crumbs.  I substitute in a little ground flaxseed mixed with hot water for the egg.  I completely omit the worcestershire due to allergies, but add in Lawry's seasoned salt, some rosemary, and thyme.  I also add in ketchup to the meat mixture.  After the meat is cooked, I use beef stock and a touch of red wine to deglaze the pan and then use the rest of the beef stock mised with flour, mustard powder, and ketchup to make the sauce.  It still tastes great to our family!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't follow the recipe exactly, but combined several other reviewer's tips. 1) Used 1.5 lbs Angus beef. 2) used italian breadcrumbs. 3) omitted salt. 4) used 1/2 packet onion soup mix and 1/2 can french onion condensed soup in the meat mixture. 5) used 1/2 can french onion condensed, 1 can beefy mushroom, 1 can cream of mushroom. 6) omitted catsup. 7) lined pyrex dish with foil, added browned patties, then covered in gravy mixture. 8) covered with aluminum foil and baked at 350 for 40 minutes. 9) sauteed onion and mushrooms to go on top. 10) served over bed of rice. It was good, could have used a bit more spice in my opinion, but nice comfort food.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This one has been asked for over & over again!  We use 3/4 can french onion soup in the ground sirloin mix and another can plus 1/4 for the gravy.  For the gravy -- once the soup is heated we scoop out about a cup of just the liquid and whisk with two TBSP flour until disolved, pour it back into the mix and stir to desired consitency for gravy. This is great over rice or mashed potatoes.  You can alter the flour mixture to get it to the thicknes you prefer.

text:
My husband has been asking for salisbury steak so I decided to give this recipe a try. I omitted the salt and added minced garlic to the meat. I followed the advice of other reviewers and added cream of mushroom soup to the gravy. I also browned the patties in a pan and finished in the oven at 375 for 30 min. The meat came out moist and flavorful but the gravy was disappointing. The french onion soup flavor was SO overpowering it almost didn't taste like gravy at all. Hubby ate it but said he wished the gravy tasted more beefy. Next time I'll just buy a can of beef gravy to put on the patties.

text:
I'd give it five stars after following some of the suggestions of the others. I did cut down on the ketchup, only using two tbs. I also used two packs of onion soup mix, one I put directly into the meat mix and the other I used with the french onion soup mix. I did not mix the french onion soup mix with the meat however, which worked out great cause the packet of onion soup mix was just enough. The other pack of soup mix I prepared per the instructions on the pack and added a little worchester's sauce and mixed in with the rest of the sauce from the recipe...yum! my daughter doesn't eat any type of "gravy" but came back for more after this. I prepared with mixed veggies and mashed potatoes, Thank you for this recipe, with a few simple tweeks its great! ( Oh yeah, very high in sodium so I suggest you omit the salt)

wow was this easy and turned out better than i imagined! i only gave 4 stars because i did have change a few things based on other review & my own additions.
I left out the egg, ketchup, worcestershire sauce, mustard powder, and instead of the canned soup I used the french onion soup powder mix and added finely chopped onion & garlic powder to ground beef mix.
I also used beef broth mixed with the flour to pour on top and baked in the oven like other users recommended.
It turned out amazing with the garlic mashed potatoes i also got from this website & will definaley use this recipe all the time! (my kids dont like mushrooms otherwise i would have added them)

okay , so  I too, hate to leave a negative rating.  But just to warn people before you  choose to try this...In my opinion, this doesn't taste like the good old fashion "brown gravy/mushroom flavored base sauce" like I have always known Salisbury  Steak to taste like.  Honestly , its the first time in years, I fed dinner to the dog, and we ordered pizza.  I was very disappointed  But there are alot of Positive ratings on it, as well.  So  just be prepared for a "different" flavor.  Maybe the canned soup just was to overpowering, leaving it with a "tart canned soup taste"....anyway, not for me.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave 4 stars because I did have to alter the recipe after reading all of the comments.  But for the most part, this is a great recipe by itself.  My alterations were as follows:   - I only used about a tablespoon of ketchup.  - I added about 3 tablespoons of A1. - I added a teaspoon of cornstarch to thicken the sauce up a bit.   - I did not drain the excess fat before adding the sauce to the patties.  - Also, I noticed the recipe doesn't mention to reduce the heat after you cover.  You'll definitely want to reduce the heat to between medium-low and medium, otherwise you'll have overcooked meat.   It turned out AMAZING!  Hubby went back for seconds and we had the left overs for lunch the next day.  It was super easy to make and tasted great!
