text:
I made this tonight and my family loved it! I made some tweaks that others had recommended. First I made the gravy with French onion soup, Lipton onion soup and cream of mushroom gravy. I mixed them together - added about 4 cups of water then added flour and thickened it. I also added some mushrooms and onions.  I made the patties and browned them then put them into a dish, covered them with the gravy and baked them. I added only about 2 Tbls of ketchup since others said to much ketchup made it to sweet and I didn't add any mustard. It was wonderful!

text:
I made this for dinner tonight.  Used all the ingredients except for prepared mustard (no dry), cut back on the ketchup (1 tsp) and added a can of mushroom condensed soup.  Everyone really enjoyed it.  I would add more flavour to the meat next time - the gravy was delicious, the texture really good (so splitting problems though I did add extra breadcrumbs - Italian).  After removing from pan I added some water to the pan as the gravy was thick.  The sauce was amazing - everyone loved it, just wanted some garlic and spices added to the meat next time - maybe a touch of hot sauce.  Otherwise it was a really good, easy meal after work.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly as described and it turned out great.  My wife and I really liked it and it was pretty easy to make.  We used lean ground beef (93%) and the patties turned out very tender.  After browning the patties, there was hardly any excess fat in the pan that needed to be drained off so we didn’t.  Homemade mashed potatoes went well with this meal but I guess that’s a no brainer.  The buttered corn worked nicely too.  The ingredients of any recipe can be altered or tweaked to individual preference or taste which I might consider doing at some point with this recipe for the sake of experimentation but, for the record, this recipe is perfectly fine as written.  I know we’ll be making it again before long.

text:
Alterations I've made that make it a 5 star (this is for 3lbs of ground beef):  One packet of onion soup mix, generous grind of pepper, some garlic powder to taste, one tbs of worch., and seasoned bread crumbs for the meat mixture.  Au Jus gravy mix, thickened with flour, for the gravy.  Browned the steaks, then poured the gravy over them, 350deg covered for 45 mins.  Fantastic!

city:

country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe, and so did my husband!   I only did a few things different, per other's reviews.  I added 1/2 of a chopped white onion and 1 clove of garlic to the meat mixture.  Also, I added 1 can of Cream of Mushroom soup and 1 packet of dry onion soup mix to the sauce mixture and I elimnated the salt all around since the soups have more than enough salt to go around!   I added water to thin the sauce out a bit, and also to dillute it since it was a little on the salty side. I doubled the amount of sauce, to accomodate for my mashed potatoes!   Also, I seared the patties on the stovetop before transfering them to a foil lined casserole dish and baked them at 400 degrees for 50 minutes (I like my meat WELL done!) - they turned out PERFECTLY - juicy and tender, not dry or rough at all!  Thanks for a GREAT recipe!

text:
This recipe was excellent.  I base my rating not only by how a dish tastes, but also how easy it is to make.  As a mom of 3, time is critical. The only substitution I made was I used a can of condensed beef broth instead of the french onion soup since I don't really care for onions in the first place, but mainly because I didn't have a can of the soup available. I also sauteed a small can of button mushrooms and added those to the grave. Really tasty dish...great recipe!!!

My BF requested Salisbury steak & I was extremely skeptical but after all the ratings and reviews I'm NOW A FAN!  I did a lot of tweaking, but believe it would be great as is.  I didn't use ketchup wanting to avoid the sugar and used organic tomato sauce instead.  I used 2 cans of roasted garlic cream of mushroom with the dry french onion soup packet.  My BF now regularly requests this.  Great with mashed potatoes or rice & green beans or asparagus.

text:
This was great and easy! The only differences I made were due to what I had on hand. I only used 1lb of hamburger but used the given measurements for everything else, I used saltines instead of breadcrumbs and I just used a squirt of yellow mustard instead of mustard powder. My BF, who is unbelievably picky, LOVED it! HE even said that I should make more sauce next time and use it for gravy over mashed potatoes! It was great! We had it with cheesy mashed potatoes and green beans.  Another note, I had absolutely no problem with these falling apart. They stuck together beautifully! Maybe it was the egg to meat ratio?

None
text:
Amazing! These are so good they are now in weekly rotation in our house. After frying them on the stove, I smother them in the gravy and bake them, covered in the oven for 20 minutes. They come out very moist and mouth-watering. They practically fall apart in your mouth and that is exactly how salisbury steak should be. I did make a few changes based on what I had on hand. I used cream of mushroom soup instead of french onion and I cut out the onions themselves. I recommend doubling the gravy recipe so that you can put it on mashed potatoes as well. Great recipe.

It was good, but not great. Used an onion soup mix (1 TBSP in steak, remainder in sauce), for not having condensed version on hand, and used cream of mushroom soup. Omitted ketchup altogether, doubled sauce recipe as recommended, & cooked in oven (pour over steaks, at 400*, 30 min). Sauce came out very thick (paste almost?), and I was expecting more like gravy, so I'll add more water for my kind of consistency (maybe evaporated in oven?). Husband's first words were, "Oh my.." in a not so good sort of way. I think it was salt content from using onion soup mix.

text:
Wow. Terribly simple, but so good! As others said, use Onion Soup Mix rather than soup itself. If you're just judging by feel like I do, get the meat mixture to feel like a meatloaf mix - not too watery. When you pan fry, just let them sit and brown, don't mess with them until you're ready to flip, and they wont' fall apart. I also used the soup mix for the gravy - excellent. Just for kicks I sauted some onion slivers to add as a garnish on top. Still getting requests from the picky eater in my house to make it again! Great recipe. Thanks!

text:
As writen, this recipe is a 3.  I messed with it a little bit, and now would rate it a 4 or 5 with the modifications.  I use cream of mushroom soup instead of the french onion that the recipe calls for.  I also add half a package of onion soup mix to the meat mixture, and the other half of the package to the gravy mixture.  After the meat simmers for 20 minutes, I remove the meat from the pan, and add 1/2 cup milk and let it thicken.  Then, I add some sauteed onion to the gravy, and pour it all on the meat and serve!  Wonderful!

This was a family hit! It was easy and my husband and kids LOVED it. They were fighting to see who was going to get to scrape the dish to get the last of the gravy.
I modified it a bit to fit what I had in the cupboard... I used a can of Campbells Select French Onion Soup and a can of their condensed Cream of Mushroom. I alos browned the patties and then baked them at 350 with the gravy on them, for about 45 minutes. 
I will definatly use this recipe again, it is wonderful!

text:
Everyone loved this.  haha, I made a bit extra, so by the end of the meal my husband had eaten a pound of meat.  I know it isn't fair to rate a recipe based on modifications, but I gave this a 5 based on the suggestions of others.  I doubled every ingredient in the sauce except for the ketchup, and I addded a can of cream of mushroom soup with garlic.  I used Italian style bread crumbs in the patties, and I added a handful of diced onions.  After browning the patties, I placed them in a foil-lined casserole dish and baked at 375 for 45 minutes with the gravy spooned on top about halfway through.  The result was really yummy... even to the fine taste-buds of the picky little brother.

Great base recipe to play with. I like to use ground turkey and make the sauce using one can cream of mushroom soup, one can beef broth, two tbsp. ketchup, minced garlic, pepper, and ground mustard. This also comes together really fast, adding even more to the allure.

I haven't had Salisbury Steak in years, I always hated it as a kid.  After trying this recipe, I have no idea why. text:
Oh man, THESE WERE GREAT!  I made them exactly how the recipe instructed and they were soooo flavorful.  Tastes just like Banquet Salisbury Steak family meals...even the sauce!  The only thing I'd suggest is doubling the gravy and maybe heat it up separately from the steaks to pour over when serving.  I didn't have hardly anything left (sauce-wise) because it was all burnt on the bottom of my skillet!  That was the only problem I had with this recipe; scraping off the very thick burnt layer of hamburger mix & sauce when cleaning up.  As you can imagine, that wasn't very fun!  So I would HIGHLY suggest baking them in the oven!!!!!  I will not be making this recipe again unless I bake them.  They might not be as good but I guess we'll see...

text:
As much as I hate to admit this, my significant other LOVES those Banquet frozen salisbury steak dinners!  I made this for him and the boys last night and voila!  Tastes JUST LIKE IT!  It's the gravy that does it.  I only put about 2.5 TBS of ketchup in though - otherwise, too overpowering.  I also strained the onions from french onion soup - boys don't like onions (the things I have to go thru!).  Thumbs up.  This is great and was very easy and quick to make.  Made with mashed pots, poured gravy over that and corn.  Boys made a KFC pie out of it (steak topped with potatoes, corn, then gravy) and loved it.  A keeper!

text:
My husband is a Salisbury Steak fan, and asked me to try my hand at making it from scratch.  Impressed by positive reviews, I gave it a whirl.  The result?  YUM!!!  The only reason I gave this recipe four stars instead of five was that after doubling the recipe for our large family, the amount of ketchup was a bit too much for the taste buds.  The texture of the Salisbury Steak was absolutely perfect (I mixed up the meat and seasonings about six hours before dinner to let the flavors mingle together) and the gravy, aside from an extra bit of tang from the ketchup, was absolutely perfect.  I didn't have any problems with the meat patties falling apart whatsoever....it truly was a wonderful dinner, and something everybody's asking me to make again.  Good thing I made enough for leftovers tonight!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a pretty good recipe, but I made some changes. When making the steak, I place the ground beef into a lg bowl and needing in about 4 slices of bread (cubed), 1 packet of Lipton cream of mushroom soup, 1 egg, and flour,and when needing it I added a little amount of water at a time. This made the bread blend in well with the meat, and instead of browning on both sides, I placed them in a lg skillet that was filled about 1/4 full of water and browned them that way not letting the pan dry out, added sliced onions, can mushrooms, 1 bf bullion cube (had no french onion on hand), made home made mashed potatoes and corn. It was very good. I have added this meal to my menu for my next months dinners, thanks for sharing.

I've never made salisbury steak before, so I wasn't sure exactly what to expect, but I loved this, and so did my husband! I used seasoned bread crumbs instead of plain(all I had) and then with the gravy, I had to put the soup in the blender to make it smooth. Hubby would've picked through the onion pieces otherwise. To make sure I had enough gravy, I added about 2/3 c. water and a beef boulion cube. This is certainly a make again recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simple and with fantastic taste.  Used a full 2 pounds of meat, omitted the mustard powder (didn't have any) and didn't feel the flavor was lacking because of it.  I left it on the stove far longer than called for, because the family was late getting home for dinner, but the steaks didn't suffer at all.  They were still tender, juicy and had great flavor.  They remind me a lot of the meatloaf I make, except they cook up in a fraction of the time!  I'll make these again for sure. **Update** I made these as meatballs for a party, and they were just as amazing as the steaks!  Browned the meatballs in a skillet, then put them in a dish, poured the sauce over and baked them till done.  Excellent!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I read the other reviews that this recipe was not authentic and tasted too much like Ketchup.  I don't know what an authentic recipe would taste like, but I know that everyone in my family ate this right up, I served with mashed potatoes and garlic beans/carrots.  I would say if you are concerned about the ketchup taste use a tomato vadalia onion salad dressing or add a can of mushroom soup, but not the regular creamed kind, try the golden one!  It is a very good idea to omit the salt no matter what.  I browned both sides of the patties on the stove with just about 1/2 tsp of olive oil (I use really lean meat), then I put it in a glazed clay 9x13 baking dish, poured the sauce over and baked it at 300 for ? until I was ready to eat, probably 1 - 1 1/2 hours.  It held together, was moist and thoroughly cooked.

text:
I'm giving this 5 stars because of MY adjustments on it and how it turned out. I read other reviews and after seeing the recipe I decided to use my own judgment and taste buds. 1st I added to the meat mixture 1/2 small onion minced, and 1 clove garlic minced, upped the bread crumbs a bit to 3/4 cup sprinkled with garlic and onion powders, salt and pepper. For the sauce, I used french onion soup and golden mushroom soup...minus the 1/3 cup french onion for the meat mixture. I added 1/3 can of water and 1/3 cup of 1/2 and 1/2 cream to the sauce as well. It was outstanding! Tasted like salisbury steak shouldI have never tasted a salisbury steak with ketchup in it...save that for meatloaf! try my version and I am sure you'll love it..I have 2 very picky children who usually turn their noses up to anything but hamburgers and mac and cheese and they kept saying "mom this is really good!" I will definitely make MY version again! My ex husband stopped by and ate with us and even HE said this was "awesome"...and you know how hard it can be to get a compliment out of an ex! LOL

text:
I took this basic recipe and adapted it to what I had in my pantry.  I started with fresh sauteed mushrooms and an envelope of onion soup mix en leu of the can of soup and 1 c water.  I spooned off 1/2 of liquid after gravy had simmered and added it to beef mixture before forming pattys.  I then added 1 c milk and flour to finish gravy sauce.  I also used crushed goldfish crackers instead of bread crumbs.  Best dish I've made according to hubby and kids!  Will be a family staple!

text:
This meal was delicious! I give the recipe 4 stars because I made some modifications that I think truly made the meal. I used less ketchup in the sauce and a package of lipton beefy onion soup mix  with the meat. I also seasoned the patties before browning them. Lastly, I cooked the steaks and gravy mixture for 30 minutes at 350 instead of on the stove (just for convenience). The seasoning of the patties was delicious and the gravy was very good. Next time I will use much less ground beef. I had about 12 regular serving size patties --more then enough for 2 people.

ADD: I cooked this on the stove finally and it is just as good and easy (but arguably more greasy).

text:
Very easy recipe! I personally give this a 5 star, however, my son and Hubby voted it a 3 star, so I compromised and ended with a 4 rating.  Very rich flavor to sauce, which I did double as suggested for serving over mashed potatoes.  I used one can of the french onion soup and added a can of Cr. of Mushroom soup.  I did cut back on the ketchup to 1/4 cup and left the remaining "spices" the same.  I thought the gravy was very good, making these glorified Hamburger patties rather tasty.  great Comfort food on a gloomy day.  Would be great with Mushrooms added, if you all like them.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This made a very tender, tasty salisbury steak, which I've always loved but have never attempted to cook before.  After reading previous reviews in which people said the sauce was a little too ketchupy, I decided to alter it a bit.  I added less ketchup, diced garlic, onion powder, and a lot of pepper.  Mmm, spicy!  I especially liked using the french onion soup, since I loathe shrooms (usually what they use).  I definitely suggest "basting" or spooning the sauce over your meat while it's cooking so that it doesn't dry out, and it gives it that authentic, juicy, coated look.  I served it with garlic mashed taters and white peas.

Someone said it tasted like meat loaf and I agree. I did not tell my daughter that becaused she does not like meat loaf. Her comment was it tasted like meat loaf without the "crunchy onions", which is what she mostly objects to. On the other hand my husband and parents all thought it was very good. I have never had Salisbury Steak with ketchup in it, so I think the name is misleading. I would probably not have made it if it had been named something else as I was looking for a meat and gravy recipe. If you are looking for a QUICK and easy "meat loaf"  you won't be disappointed.

This one's a keeper! I took the advice of some of the others and used less ketchup, (about half of what is called for) & doubled up on the sauce. It was very tasty! However, we had leftovers the next day and it was even better! Like, ten times better!!! The meat was soooo tender the second day; next time I think I'll make it a day ahead and let it sit in the fridge overnight, then heat it up and serve the next day. I served this with mashed potatoes, but I think it would be great over egg noodles too.

text:
This was a delicious recipe.  I love salisbury steak and had been craving it for several weeks when I found this recipe.  My boyfriend thought it was a silly thing to like b/c it reminded him of cafeteria food.  We ate this with mashed potatoes, green beans, and carrots.  He decided it is a keeper!  I did make a few modifications:  cream of mushroom soup instead of french onion soup, the bread crumbs were seasoned with onion soup mix, adding 1/2 cp water and 1/2 cp milk to make extra gravy, extra onion flakes sprinkled into the meat and the gravy, 1 additional Tbsp worcestershire sauce, and no ketchup (didn't have it).  The gravy was fine without the ketchup.  I think it would have made the gravy too sweet/tangy.

text:
When this recipe first posted (I have a printout from 4/27/00 and have been enjoying it since), it read "1 can condensed onion soup".  I didn't use french onion - I used cream of onion - and loved it.  You could save on some calories and fat by using low-fat cream of mushroom and a partial packet of dry onion soup as well. (Campbell's doesn't offer low-fat cream of onion.) I never had a problem with patties falling apart or gravy not thickening with the cream soups.

text:
VERY, VERY good! Whole family loved it! Hubby liked it so much no one was allowed to have seconds because he wanted to take leftovers to work! I did add half a package dry onion soup mix to meat mixture, for sauce I omitted ketchup, and added can cream mushroom soup, 1/4 cup brown gravy mix, and doubled the water. Didn't have any mustard powder, so used a squirt liquid mustard. after browning patties, I put in large casserole poured sauce on top, and baked 30 minutes at 400 degrees

text:
I made this for dinner the other night and everyone loved it. It is rare that EVERYONE really likes what I make for dinner. I did read is some reviews that the patties fell apart. I used ground chuck, cooked them on med high and flipped them only once. I turned them down to low when I added the soup mixture. If you stick to the recipe and only use the french onion instead of the cream soups, the meat will hold together. Also, make sure that the ketchup is well blended with the soup before you add it to the pan. The best part about it was that it was very simple and easy to make. I will definitely make this again.

This was good, I did do alot of altering though, after reading other reviews. Display Name:
OHIOMOM1

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1207029.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for my family tonight and we all liked it a lot, including my extremely picky 3-year-old son. The only modifications I made were:
 I added 1/2 tsp. of onion powder, garlic powder and 1 T. of parsley (to give it that true salisbury steak appearance) to the meat mixture. 
 according to past reviewers, I cut down the mustard powder to 1/4 tsp, instead of 1/2 tsp. 
 instead of frying on the stove, I baked them at 375 degrees for 25 minutes in a glass casserole dish, drained, then added the gravy and baked an additional 10 minutes and the meat was "well done". 

I found them very juicy and they didn't fall apart. There was no leftovers, which is unusual for us! 
This is a great recipe - definitely a keeper!

text:
This is delicious!  The only reason I gave it four stars is because I changed some stuff.  I used Cream of Mushroom instead of onion, and added an onion soup packet.  I didn't add any of the cream of mushroom to the meat, and my steaks held together perfectly.  I only used one pound of meat.  I added some beef broth to the gravy to make it richer.  It is sooo good!

text:
The first time I made this, I didn't pay attention to the directions and added the entire can of french onion soup to the hamburger - it was a soupy, yucky mess.  The second time, I followed the recipe with the exception of the changes recommended by other reviewers...can of cream of mushroom, no ketchup, added water to the pan after frying the patties and scraped the leavings into the sauce mix, baked for 30 minutes with sauce.  When following the directions and recommendations of other reviewers, it was VERY GOOD!  Definitely an addition to our meal rotation.

text:
This was good as far as salisbury steak goes.  I would suggest using a very lean beef.  Without thinking I used a pretty cheap ground beef, and it ended up being pretty greasy (since there's no way to drain it before the meat is fully cooked, only right after the patties are browned).  But even so it was still good and my husband asked me to make it again.  I like recipies that don't require removing all the pans from my oven and heating up the entire kitchen :)  Also, next time I'll probably look for a low-sodium soup.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1962.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family LOVED this dish - but I, naturally, made some changes to it (as any good cook would).  I added a LOT more bread crumbs to the mixture than was called for, as I thought it looked a bit, well, sloppy.  I'm glad that I did, because in all honesty, it broke apart anyway!  :-)  I also added less ketchup to the sauce than was called for, and a bit less Worcestershire - the color of the sauce outright scared me.  I also added 2 cans of mushrooms.  In the end, this dish was WONDERFUL, despite the fact that it all broke apart.  One thing I noticed, however, was that the sauce only took 5 minutes to cook up and NOT 20 - if I had left it on for 20 minutes, I would have had a black, burned mess!  I will be making this again without a doubt.  Thanks for the recipe, Kelly!

I tried this recipe as yet another attempt to get my children to eat the elusive ground beef.  It worked!  Great recipe, super quick, easy, and frugal too!  The patties kept their shape yet did not come out dry or need to be soaked in sauce. Next time I will try it with green peppercorn sauce.

text:
I went with some suggested modifications. I added a small amount of vegetable oil to skillet. Browned both sides of patty and added sauce. I replaced most of the sauce ingredients with instant brown gravy powder. Used 2 Tbsp of Worcestershire sauce. Also added a can of cream of mushroom soup, and 8 oz fresh, sliced mushrooms. Cover and simmer for 40 minutes. Whole family loved it!

text:
I have made this a few times and I give it five stars, because it is simple, outcome is consistent and flavor is great. I do start with the base recipe and make additions. I use two pounds of ground. I usually mix one pound of beef and one pound of venison. I like lots of sauce, so I use two cans of soup: one french onion and one golden mushroom. To the sauce, I also add a handful of sliced mushrooms and a little bit of paprika. With this, I always make homemade mashed potatoes and cream corn.

text:
I seared the meat and placed in an 11x9 baking dish. I then added some more butter and sauteed the onions and mushrooms. I deglazed the pan with some red wine 1/4 cup. I also used dry onion soup mix and added water and some beef bouillon along with the rest of the ingredients listed. After the gravy was made, I poured the gravy over the meat in the pan. Then finished cooking the meat at 350 for 20 minutes or until desired doneness. It was delicious.

5

city:

country:
None
text:
Came out really GOOD! I changed a few things. I used mustard instead of mustard seed/mustard powder. And I added Au jus to the French onion mixture. I also added a tea spoon of liquid smoke. Make sure it's just a bit. It'll over power everything. I seasoned the meat with mustard, pink Himalayan salt. Grinded black pepper, liquid smoke ( I season the eggs with liquid smoke), garlic powder. I used the French onion for the gravy. Added Au jus, sautéed Vidalia onions, 3 garlic cloves and a few bay leaves. I’m telling you, it takes the dish from down home to gourmet. Im a self taught chef. I love putting my own spin on things

text:
I did NOT use the condensed onion soup. Instead I mixed I/4  packet of dry onion soup mix  and mixed it  with the ground beef along with the other ingredients.  I then made the rest of the dry onion soup according to package directions and simmered my burgers in it until done.  I agree with another reviewer in that using the dry soup mix  is much better.  I tried making  the gravy/sauce  according to the recipe and it was not good.  I plan on making these again.

text:
My boyfriend is a HUGE fan of the Hungry Man Salisbury Steak frozen dinner you can find in the supermarket. This was a delicious recipe. It was just what we needed. I paired it with pasta salad, mashed potatoes, biscuits, peas and carrots. It is a lot of carbs, haha! But the dinner was so comforting. Pure comfort food. I followed just about everything to a T. The ONLY difference was to add 1/2 C of water instead of 1/4. It was a very small alteration. I wanted a little extra gravy to pour over my mashed potatoes. 

But as this little difference does not alter the recipe ingredients much, I must say, this recipe just as it is was PHENOMENAL. Thank you!!! :-D

text:
The first time I made this I followed the recipe and we loved it! The second time I didn’t have all of the ingredients so made some adaptations. I used 1 lb ground beef and 1/2 lb ground pork, 1 can of cream of mushroom soup, a packet of Lipton’s Onion and Mushroom soup mix, some fresh pressed garlic, and a soup can of red wine instead of water. I didn’t need to add any salt or pepper. It was delicious and I’m sorry I didn’t make more! Thank you for the recipe!

Display Name:
volsheels

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Since my family (2 adults with 2 kids) like leftovers, I tripled some of the recipe and made some modifications.  To make the patties, I used 4.5 pounds of lean ground beef, one can of condensed French onion soup, 1 cup dry bread crumbs (meant to put in 1.5 cups, but forgot to add the last 1/2 cup), 1 package of Lipton onion soup mix, 2 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce, 3 eggs, and ground pepper (didn’t measure).  I made 16 patties.  I browned them in the skillet, then placed in a couple of casserole dishes.  For the gravy I mixed 3 jars of beef gravy, 1 jar of mushroom gravy, 2 cans of cream of mushroom soup and 1 Tbsp of Worcestershire sauce (my family loves gravy with their rice - I’m adding a picture so you can see how much gravy I had so you can adjust accordingly).  I poured this over the patties and baked 45 minutes on 350.  The family loved it and we’ll definitely be making this again.

I made this right before Christmas. Had all my kids at home , so 9-10 mouths to feed. I tripled  up on the recipe , and tweaked it just a tad, as my small kids are picky eaters. This was a hit ! I figured I'd have left overs.... I had 3 steaks left...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe verbatim and the patties held their shape and I found the sauce the be tasty unlike many of the reviews I read.

I chose this recipe because when I normally make Salisbury steaks I will carmelize 1.5 onions.  After carmelizing, I take 1/2 of the onions mince them and place them into the patties. The other half I use for the gravy.  I also find crushed saltines will provide a much more tender texture to the patties than bread crumbs. I did not have saltines on hand today and quite frankly was feeling on the lazy side and I had a can of canned French onion soup.

For a recipe that cuts down time and effort, I found it to be good and my fiancé enjoyed it. It may have been a tad saltier than my normal recipe but it’s good and and was very easy to follow!

Decided to make this recipe because it was rated 4 1/2 stars with over 3,000 reviews.  This receipe was hands-down the absolute worst recipe I have ever tried on this site.  I'm not even that picky of a person either.  I made the recipe exactly with no changes.  Too much bread crumbs...made the meat have a terrible texture.  The sauce...where do I start. text:
I was intrigued by this recipe because of the French Onion soup and dry mustard. So, decided to give it a try. I stayed pretty true to the recipe only adding sautéed onions and fresh mushrooms and adjusting some measurements since I only used a pound of ground beef. I pan fried my patties until they got a good sear on the outside, pulled them out of the pan, added back in the onions, mushrooms and gravy ingredients and then finished in the oven at 350 for 30 minutes. Served with mashed potatoes and peas! Yummy!

country:

text:
4 stars because I made my own changes from the very beginning - I don't like mustard and ketchup so I removed those. I took reviewers advice and for gravy I had 1 can cream of mushroom and 1 can french onion soup and like 1/4 pack of dry onion soup mixed,  with pepper, a little flour because I was scared it would clump [and it  did so I was glad i didn't put much]. For the meat I followed recipe minus salt, added splash of Worcestershire's sauce and 1/2 pack of dry onion soup. I fried them in skillet with butter and 2 tsp of  minced garlic [from the jar] . Turned out really good [5 stars! ] with the garlic potatoes recipe  from here, side was butter corn though I think green beans would be better, and sweet Hawaiian rolls. My boyfriend loved it! We'll be making this often and this is still great as leftovers!

text:
Salisbury steak is a very popular meal in Japan, where I grew up, but the sauce is very different. This sauce made mostly from French onion soup and Worcestershire sauce plus the kick from mustard is a new experience to my taste buds (and my family's) and they are all very happy about it. I found the recipe about a month ago and I have already made it 3 times. So, yes, we definitely approve! I do not use ketchup, do use Lipton Onion Soup Mix, and I definitely double the amount of gravy. I make a lot of garlic mashed potatoes with this and we can enjoy the left over mashed potatoes and gravy in the next few days. Great recipe!

I made this almost as the recipe called for except I added one tbsp of Worcestershire sauce to the meat mixture and one to the sauce mixture an oversight. (Oops) either way it was a hit. Everyone home for dinner said it was awesome. We had it with mashed potatoes and sautéed whole green beans. Very easy to make, ingredient list was easy most things already in the pantry and best of all no mushrooms !  I’m allergic so usually I cannot eat Salisbury steak so I was very happy to find this recipe. I honestly do not think the recipe needs any adjusting (except if you have more than 4 people or teenage boys make a double batch) Saving this to my favorites and will make it again for sure.

text:
Very solid 4 star review.  I dropped the amount of ketchup a bit.  I could not find canned French Onion soup, so I made a half packet of dried beefy onion soup mix as a substitute.

We enjoyed it very much.  A nice richness to the sauce, but not too sweet, good balance.  Also quick and easy, which is a benefit for me.  Using the dried soup also gives me flexibility on cutting the recipe down (only 2 of us), although the leftovers were easy to reheat for lunch, so either way works.

text:
Great meal for a school night. I'm always looking for ground beef recipes that aren't hamburgers, and this is a great option. Pretty much everything is generally on hand all of the time. Since I've made this so often, I've started stocking french onion soup in my pantry so I'm always ready for those busy nights that didn't get much time for planning.  My tip, once you've decided this one's for supper, set your ground beef out of the fridge about 30 minutes (or as close as you can manage) ahead of mixing. The beef will retain juices better, and your hands will thank you for not being wrist deep in freezing cold meat while you mix and shape. I hope you enjoy this one as much as we have. Bon appetit. :)

I made a concentrated onion soup from packet onion soup mix from $1 store, meaning I added half the water the soup packet said to use for onion soup. I then made a mushroom gravy packet mix (i buy low sodium versions at my grocery store, use could use just Brown gravy mix). You use part off the concentrated onion soup for the hamburger mix. I then combined the leftover onion soup, with the gravy mix with the rest of the recipes ingredients.  and poured over the parties in the aluminum foil lined and covered banking dish. Served with streamed cauliflower with cheese sauce.  Easy & delish!

text:
Update: Made as written and using the can of French onion soup resulted in a nice brown sauce, unlike the orange color I previously experienced. I still think it needs the can of mushroom soup which also gives more delicious sauce to drizzle over side dishes. Original review: I totally agree with the previous reviewer saying it’s unfair to make numerous changes to a recipe then give it a low rating. However, sometimes I make changes based on what I have on hand and I like to see if anyone else may have tried these changes. For instance, I did not have any French onion soup and I wondered if anyone made it with a packet of Lipton soup mix instead (and found several comments about how it worked out for them). Changes I made: I sprinkled 1/2 a packet of onion soup mix with 2 oz of water and 1/2 of a finely chopped onion to the meat mixture. For the sauce, I used the full 1/4 cup of ketchup but I will reduce it next time. I also added a can of cream of mushroom soup and 2 cups of water, which I will also do again. The sauce turned out to be kind of an orange color instead of a deep brown but I don’t think it was off putting.

userID:
22875554
Display Name:
Denisa McCallum
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
11
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7262008.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thank you so much for this recipe! It was delicious.  After reading the reviews before making it, I did add and change a couple of things.  I have a family of six, so for the meat patties I used 2lbs of lean ground beef, I sautéed 1/2 cup of finely chopped onion and one clove of garlic in 1 tablespoon of butter, 1 can of French onion soup,  and followed everything else.  I then formed the patties (was able to make 9)and put themin the fridge for about a 1/2 hour.  
I  cooked the beef patties in a frying pan just searing them on both sides ( I had no trouble with the meat falling apart) then placed the patties in a 13x9 baking dish and preheated the oven to 375 degrees, using the same pan that I cooked the patties in, I sautéed a large container of mushrooms, in another pan I made the gravy by  adding  1 packet of organic brown gravy mix, 1 cup water, 2 cans of French onion soup, 1 can of organic cream of mushroom soup, regular amount of ketchup, doubled the worschestire sauce and mustard powder, I didn't add any flour or salt since the brown gravy packet already had corn starch and seasoning in it, brought it all to a boil, then added my sautéed mushrooms to it, poured the gravy mixture over the patties, placed in the oven covered with foil for 40 min.  We love gravy so I was glad I doubled that. I served the Salisbury steaks with mashed potatoes, corn and broccoli.  My husband and kids loved it and I plan on making this again and again.

userID:
12903375
Display Name:
J. King
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think this recipe is perfect as presented but I can’t make gravy and I didn’t have all the right ingredients. Some folks get annoyed when you modify recipes; if that’s you then stop reading. First, I bought the best low fat ground beef that I could find. I doubled my ingredients and made 8 patties.  I used a dried pack of onion soup mix and also added a chopped medium sized onion because we really like onions.  And I also added about a 1/4 cup of spicy mustard because it seemed like a good idea at the time. We like our hamburger meat cooked well done, so after frying the patties, I baked them for 45 minutes on 375 in the oven. My gravy always turns out a disaster, so I chose to use 2 packs of McCormicks brown gravy mix, a package of dried onion soup, and a can of cream of mushroom soup mixed with 3 or 4 cups of water (I didn’t use a measure) and then heated to a low boil until it thickened up.  That’s a lot of gravy.  After the steaks came out of the oven, I dropped them in the gravy and served them with instant potatoes and a side of green beans that I’d cooked all day with salt pork. Everybody loved it and came back for seconds. This is on my top ten list.
Review:

text:
Excellent! Reduced to four servings as I only had one pound of ground beef. I couldn't find condensed french onion soup ANYWHERE, so I substituted dried onion soup mix (roasted garlic onion version). One third of the package into the meat mixture with a bit of water and the rest I made into a gravy with the rest of the water and added all of the mentioned ingredients. I always add extra veggies into my meat mixture to get more into the meal, so I added onions and mushrooms. Be sure to cut them finely because they kind of made the patties fall apart a bit from being too big. Did them on the stovetop as indicated and they turned out perfectly. Will definitely make again and will keep hunting for that condensed soup!

text:
Was craving comfort food on a cold, wet evening and found this recipe. I did not have a can of French onion soup, but I did have a can of beef broth and a package of onion soup mix.  This substitution worked well.  I followed the recipe pretty close beyond there with the exception of the amount of ketchup. I  didn't want it to have that sweet, ketchup taste. I did not measure but squirted a bit into the pan. (maybe 2-3 tbsp.?) Anyway, in the end it was delicious.  It did not however make enough gravy to go over potatoes or noodles, etc. We did not have anything but the meat patties, but if you are looking forward to having gravy to pour over something else then you will want to double the recipe.  My family really liked this dinner (they all asked for seconds!). I gave it 4 stars due to the fact that it doesn't make enough gravy. The flavor was good, but it was not enough even to cover the patties.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Rating the recipe made as-is with only two minor revisions: I didn't have condensed soup so I used Lipton onion soup mix and 10.5oz of water (made ahead) and panko bread crumbs because that's what I had. 

The patties held together fine: the secret is to use medium high heat and flip them only once before adding the sauce: the patties should have a crisp crust when you flip them the first time and again on the second side before you add the sauce. Do that, and they'll keep their structure. 

The sauce was kid-friendly, which is to say tangy and flavourful without being too strong or complex. That bring said I enjoyed it too. I would definitely consider adding mushrooms and/or sauteed onions if I were making this for adults.
Review:

2

text:
This was super easy.  The condensed French Onion soup really makes this dish.  I used 1 lb of ground beef adjusting the patty ingredients accordingly.  It made 4 oval patties about 3/4 thick and 5 inches long.  I made the gravy mixture as directed.  It made plenty of gravy to spoon over freshly made mashed potatoes.  Yum! My preference would be to use JUST slightly less ketchup as  the gravy had more tomato taste than I prefer.  The Worcestershire sauce gave it a nice zing.

text:
Very good and easy recipe overall. Two suggestions on execution: 
1. Use a large egg rather than extra large. Ex lrg egg makes patties too soft.
2. Brown the flour in the fat rather than mix it with liquid ingredients, as this gives the sauce a bit more depth.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have a Gluten allergy, so I modified this recipe so that I could enjoy it...and it worked beautifully. 
I started out frying 2 large onions sliced thin in 1/4 cup real butter. Salt the onions to bring out the flavor. After they're cooked soft, I add 1 cup hot water with 2 beef bullion cubes and 1 teaspoon Worcester sauce. Boil just until cubes are dissolved.  I substitute this for canned French onion. I followed the rest of this recipe substituting Gluten free bread crumbs and flour that are easy to find. Delish!

I loved making this.  As much as I don't like people who alter recipes...I had to because my girls  don't like onions or mushrooms. userID:
22145757
Display Name:
Mandee North
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never had Salisbury steak, but remember looking at congealed and greasy offerings of it in grade school and college. I passed on to the other option...
Well, I had 2lbs of ground beef to use and wanted a quick dinner. I had to alter this recipe a little bit because I am gluten free, but let me say this will be a quick and easy dinner staple in my home now!
I used two packets of dry french onion soup, and while it was delicious it came out a little too salty. One packet wouldn't have been enough- so between a third and half of the second will be tested next time.
Because I did not have the condensed onion soup, I substituted with Progresso's cream of mushroom (GFree!) instead.
I used cornmeal as breadcrumbs, and had stuck them in my little food processer to get a slightly finer texture. I put in some spices (we use seasoned), and two eggs to bind the hamburger patties.
While they were browning in the pan, I chopped some mushrooms and popped red potatoes in the microwave... drained off the grease, put in the rest of the soup-gravy recipe  (we love Worcestershire sauce so i added more) with the mushrooms and let it simmer.
I made smashed garlic potatoes and boy this dinner really hit the spot of comfort food which was quick, easy, AND gluten free. My dad thinks GFree is gross- but he had two helpings!! We didn't tell him otherwise!

Display Name:
Kim Sinclair

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3289820.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Taking from the reviews of others I added/omitted to the recipe.  Isn't that what helps a recipe grow and improve!  

I left out the ketchup, mustard, salt and pepper.  Used Garlic and Herb bread crumbs, egg and 1/3 can French Onion Soup.  Browned patties and transferred to crock pot on low.  In a different pan sauteed an onion and sliced mushrooms in butter then poured on top of the meat.  Added more butter to pan and made a rue.  Added the rest of the French onion soup, 1/2 of a mini bottle of Chardonnay, can of Cream of Mushroom soup and milk until I liked the texture and taste.  Left in crock pot on low for three hours and served over brown rice with fresh green beans.  AMAZING!!!!!!  Yes my patties crumbled a bit, yes it took a bit of work but I think this is the best meal that I have ever cooked.  I am adding it to the rotation.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good. Never seen or ever heard of a can of French Onion Soup however. Use onion soup mix & 2c water, then hold the salt! Add med onion fine chop to the beef. Fry patties in bacon fat or 3 TBS Crisco for flavour; drain, but first sautée some shrooms. Deglaze pan w sherry/red wine. Double the gravy ingreds but omit ketchup. Dissolve a bouillon cube or 2  in hot water to increase. Add a splash of sherry. Thicken gravy with corn starch slurry vs flour; adjust seasonings. The oven is unnecessary. 
Serve with boiled potatoes and green beans. 
.

region:

country:
None
text:
The only change I made was instead of dry bread crumbs, I used three slices of bread with crust removed dissolved  I into 1/2 cup of cold water. Leave it sit for 10 mins then beat with a fork to combine. I do the same for meatballs and the meat comes out so tender and juicy, never dry or hard.  When I make it again I may use less Worcestershire sauce and french onion soup in the sauce. It was very good but a little more tart than I expected. I might saute some fresh onions to go along with the french onion soup and add a little water. It did thicken quite a bit after 20 mins of simmering so a little water wouldn't hurt maybe 1/2 cup. I'm used to Salisbury steak being more like a beef gravy, maybe I've just never had the real thing... Overall it was very good and I'll make it again. My 4 year old even liked it (except for the onions) so we'll definitely try it again soon!

userID:
9064122
Display Name:
hillrakz

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This salisbury steak was great! Made for a routine weekday dinner as a new meal to shake things up a bit. The "steaks" were tender and the sauce came out creamy and delish.  I read others reviews and took advice that several reviewers gave- added condensed cream of mushroom soup. I wasn't sure how much mushroom soup to add so I put in approximately half of the 10.5 oz can then added a little more water for better consistency. My husband and I tasted the sauce and agreed it needed more beef flavor so I opted for a beef bullion cube and it did the trick. The meal turned out great, patties stayed together nicely and I topped it with sautéed mushrooms and onions for serving with an easy side of mac & cheese. We had leftovers and my son crumbled and mixed it into the mac & cheese for the next night's for dinner. When I make this again, I will combine the liquid sauce ingredients with the flour in the warmed pan (will take steaks out temporarily) so the flour dissolves more easily, I really had to work it this go round to get rid of the flour lumps. Thanks for posting this easy and tasty dinner!

I only gave a 4 because I was out of french onion soup and had to wing it a little - used onion soup mix, put half in the meat and half in the sauce.  I tweaked the meat a little due to taste as well, added garlic and put Worcestershire in the meat in addition to the sauce. It is a little heavy on the ketchup for our taste, but does take me back to my Mom making this when I was a kid.  Had this with mashed potatoes and asparagus that we canned last season.

text:
We really liked this.  I had to make 2 substitutions.  I did not have the onion soup but did have beef consommé, so used that instead.  I probably should have sautéed some onions to make it closer to the original recipe.  I also used evaporated milk in place of the soup in the beef patties.  I had made a similar recipe using that in the past.  In doing that I had enough left over sauce to put over mashed potatoes.  Added peas and had a complete winter comfort dinner.

text:
I used one pound of ground sirloin to make this recipe, so I had to adjust this quite a bit, but it worked out well.  I did add some garlic powder to the meat mixture and I substituted wine for the water as other reviewers suggested.  I also added some mushrooms that needed to be used up.  This was good and Hubs liked it a lot, but I didn’t care for the ketchup in this.  It contributed a slightly sweet flavor to the gravy that I didn’t care for.  Even though this one wasn’t for me, I’m glad I tried it.

Display Name:
Chef Mom

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've never made Salisbury steak before, and this was a very easy copycat recipe. My husband and 4yo daughter enjoyed it. My changes were having a little less than 1lb of meat, used seasoned stuffing rather than bread crumbs, omitted the mustard powder, and made my gravy like a southerner (doubled recipe, thicker, and used the grease drippings from the "steaks"). Fried the meat patties, cooked thoroughly then set aside to rest. Topped them with the hot gravy as we made our plates. Likely, I will attempt a more traditional Salisbury steak recipe next time the craving calls , but this one has been added to the family recipe rolladex, anticipating my daughter's to want easy beginner recipes in their teen years.
Review:
Rating:
2
dateLastModified:
2016-06-12T00:40:25.09

Pleasantly surprised by this recipe!  It was very easy and didn't take a lot of clean-up, which is HUGE for me! Next time I'll try some of the gravy suggestions and minimize the amount of ketchup I use... that's more of a personal/family preference rather than a criticism.  I may also make minor modifications on the steaks to add a bit more flavor to the meat.  Overall, I was very happy with how the meal turned out.  The meat was nicely cooked and held together well, while maintaining juice and flavor.  I will definitely make this meal again.

Of alllll the Salisbury Steak recipes I've tried, this is the favorite. I've made it exactly as is and loved it and now that I've made it a regular on our home menu, I'll make occasional variations depending on what's hiding in my pantry because it really is wonderfully versatile. I ALWAYS double the sauce now though just because I am a saucy kinda gal and the family likes putting it on mashed potatoes or egg noodles so we need a bit more. Try it as is then put your own spin on it if you want but it's best starting point recipe for sure.

Great recipe. Quick and easy to make but sooo juicy!
I followed the suggestions and added some condensed cream of mushroom soup to the sauce, and cut down the ketchup a bit. I substituted the mustard powder with Dijon mustard, and added some crushed red peppers. 
I also added some chopped up garlic and onions to the beef mixture. 
The steaks held their shape well in the pan.

text:
Loved this. The only changes I made were that I used powdered onion soup mix  (I could NOT find a can of French onion anywhere!!)  and a can of cream of mushroom. I added fresh mushrooms and followed the rest of the instructions EXCEPT:
For those of you who keep having them fall apart, an easy fix is to omit the egg. Instead soak your breadcrumbs in some milk - just enough to wet them and have them soak up the milk but not soggy - and mix that in. Works every time.

It's amazing! Add another condensed soup of your choice(I used cream of mushroom) a Lipton onion soup package-so no salt! And bit more water... text:
I made this exactly as listed and the was great.  The whole family loved it.  The sauce was a little bit "ketchup'y, but I thought that made it good.  The only thing I would change next time is to make double the sauce.  We had these "steaks" with mashed potatoes, and extra gravy is always a good thing with mashed potatoes.  I didn't have any problem with the patties falling apart, but I did put them in the fridge for about 1/2 hour because I was waiting for my potatoes to boil.  This is a great quick and good weeknight recipe.

text:
This is one of our family favorites. I have made this recipe at least ten times and there are never any leftovers! I like extra gravy so I add another can of French Onion soup when mixing everything up and more of the ketchup, A1, mustard (actual mustard) to taste with another tablespoon of flour. If I have fresh mushrooms on hand I throw them in the pan when the patties are browning and leave them in with the sauce. I serve it with homemade mash potatoes, a veggie and corn bread muffins. Awesome recipe. P.S. I don't add any water to the sauce. We like it thick.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this and thought from the reviews that it would be great.    But this wasn't the case.    To the gravy, I had added dry Lipton onion soup mix, a can mushroom soup, 2 tsp brown gravy mix and about 1/4 can beef stock.  I sauteed the mushrooms before adding to the gravy mixture, drained them  too.

I then seared the steaks and transferred to a casserole dish, covered with the gravy mixture and baked @ 350 degrees for 40 min.

My family didnt like the overpowering onion taste.  (I had used the french onion soup as directed.)  Next time will omit this and just use the Lipton onion dry mixture.

Overall, it was OK but not as the other reviews rave about.
I had high hopes for my Sunday supper, but was not to be.

Made this with mashed potatoes, buttered corn and homemade bread.   Was not enough to save the main dish.

Also, if you do make this, make sure you drain EVERYTHING.  I used 90% lean hamburger and still had alot of grease sitting on the top of the gravy.  Not appetizing at all.

text:
Fabulous!  New family favorite.  Never made Salisbury steak before in 34 years of cooking, don't know why! I did make changes.  I used 2 pds of beef with 1 pound of ground pork.
Also added small finely diced onion .   Since I had such a large amount of meat I put whole can of soup in mixture along with one package of onion soup.   I was worried it would be too salty so I did not add salt and it turned out great.  Browned them in skillets and transferred them to deep casserole dish, covered and baked for about 45 minutes (mine were very thick).  Also doubled the amount of gravy.  Thanks for this recipe!

text:
Pretty good. I made this over my bf's house with no measuring utensils so I eyeballed the measurements and I also used a can of cream of mushroom. About 1/3 with the patties and the rest in the gravy. I also added the dry onion soup..about 3/4 of a packet plus a cup or so of water. I didn't add salt..just pepper. Other than that I followed the recipe exactly and my bf and his very picky 7 yr. old enjoyed it. The onion taste was pretty strong to me but next time I think I'll add a bit of sugar and adjust the gravy to taste. I'll also use cubed steaks. Great base recipe tho!

Display Name:
Joy M

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely THE best.  I've made this several times.  It is a quick and easy recipe and I serve with mashed potatoes and a vegetable (usually broccoli).  The condensed French Onion soup is hard to come by sometimes, so I just substitute a packet of onion soup mix and add that to 10.5 oz of hot water.  

Recently I wanted to leave some for my family while I was away and followed the directions up to shaping the patties then froze the patties separately in plastic wrap.  I made the gravy on the stove, let it cool and spooned it into a small zip lock baggie and put the frozen patties and gravy baggie in a larger freezer zip lock with written instructions on the outside for them.  They loved it, so simple and quick!  I imagine you could cook completely then freeze as well.... that is my next experiment.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
the weakest ingredient is the can of Onion soup.  Hot water, tablespoon of quality beef stock concentrate, caramelize a white onion, add to stock and let it get happy.  Many improvements suggest throwing a can of mushroom soup at the recipe to improve. 

The basic recipe is very good.  If you ditch the can onion soup and make real onion soup, it is wonderful.  

What I'm trying to say here is the time saved by dumping a can of soup at a recipe like this isn't worth the time saving as you get a can soup result.

I tried this recipe, today.  I would have gave it the 5 th star, but i had to change a few things. I used pre -made burger patties , instead of making my own with the flavors of the recipe. Just salt, pepper, and garlic powder. I didnt have the onion soup mix and onion soup, so i used a powdered ranch dip mix , cream of chicken soup and dried minced onions. I also added more water because we like the gravey on mashed potatoes. Turned out pretty good, thin burgers do better than thicker ones, i had both. The gravey was good, not too thick, I put an extra tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce, wont do that again, too much. I was trying to darken the gravey. Otherwise, great inspiration.  Thanks !

I may take others recipe and either broil the tops and then pour gravy over, or just not pan-sear first. also i prefer using the Lipton onion soup/ cream of mushroom soup gravy. One plus is I can buy the ingredients in bulk/family pack and make ahead lots of patties and freeze. Since its only myself and my husband it makes it easy to have a nice meal without having to prepare from scratch every time.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I had a few problems with this recipe, but it was my own fault.  Despite that, this is a very forgiving recipe.  When it called for a large frying pan, I was a little too literal and got out my 15" diameter pan.  The largest of three nesting cast iron pans would have been great.  I only had golden mushroom soup, one pound of hamburger, and seasoned bread crumbs, but even with those alterations, the flavor of the dish was wonderful.  I was worried that the flavor would be like a sloppy Joe, being it called for ketchup and mustard, but there was no resemblance.  I like sloppy Joes, I just didn't want that tonight. The burgers did stick to the pan, and I ended up just breaking up the burgers so the sauce wouldn't burn, too, which it was close to doing.  As I said, my pan was too big.  I cooked up some egg noodles and stirred it all together.  I enjoyed it; I'll be curious to try it with the actual ingredients called for; I'm sure it will be even better.  I found it a bit on the salty side, but that could be because I only used  one pound vs. one and a half pounds of meat.

country:

text:
Update 10/17/14 
This update concerns the mustard powder and ketchup I was out of the first time I prepared this recipe. I made this again and added the missing ingredients. Our preference: This recipe, for us, was better without the mustard and ketchup. The flavor was beefier. The ketchup added a sweetness that we did not care for. 

I tried this recipe a few weeks ago and my family and I loved it. I was out of mustard powder and ketchup but they still were delicious. The next time I prepare this recipe I will add those two items in and see if there is much difference in taste and decide which way we like it best. I thought the rich beefy flavor the French onion soup provided was super. I added a bit more soup than required because I wanted to have plenty of gravy for the mashed potatoes we had with the steaks. Add a salad or veggie and you have a great meal. I have an additional suggestion that many of you probably already do to cut down on kitchen time. Every meal I prepare I double or triple the recipe. We enjoy leftovers and this cuts down on my cooking time. My family does not mind to eat the same thing two days in a row but you could always reheat it 2-3 days later or freeze it in portions. I am a homeschool mom with two of my sons still in high school and there are days they have the leftovers for their lunch or even a snack. It is nice to have the prepared food handy as it cuts down on what I consider junk food.

text:
I made this recipe almost as stated.  I did read most of the reviews and added a few things.  I added finely chopped onions to my beef mixture along with 2 cloves minced garlic.  I made a larger portion so I include a can of golden mushroom soup.  I did add an extra TBSP of flour.  Everything turned out great! And the leftovers just kept tasting better.  I found that the gravy was too watery and I did have to thicken it with a cornstarch slurry.  This really was such a great recipe. The mixture of the French Onion soup and and Golden Mushroom really made a nice gravy when thickened.  I served it with egg noodles and green beans.  My first time making Salisbury steaks and everyone loved it...thanks for the recipe.  A real keeper and thanks for the reviews from fellow cooks on how to tweak it.

text:
This recipe is to become a family favorite. My wife and I tag-teamed, as we usually do, on this meal and were so pleased with the outcome even though we made a few changes do to supplies on hand and personal preferences. We only used a pound of ground chuck so had to modify everything by a third... all but the soup. For the soup we used Lipton's Beefy Onion and halved the amount of water giving us a little more gravy. This was awesome. A trick I've gotten hooked on is using bacon grease to brown the meat. Mmm-mmmm Good!!

country:
None
text:
This is outstandingly delicious with the following modifications: double the gravy (except for the ketchup) and added a can of cr. of mushroom soup and beef-onion soup mix. I cooked the patties in a couple of tablespoons of butter to get a crispy outside. Even with a lot of pink in the middle, these cooked through beautifully with the gravy simmering for about twenty-ish minutes. I sauteed 1 lb. mushrooms and one large  onion and then, when cooked through, I added them to the steaks and gravy just before serving. Served with mashed red potatoes. YUM! We both loved this recipe. :) In fact, my husband said it was one we'd have to make again and again and again.

text:
in my opinion, this sauce was awful! i am pregnant and had a strong craving for salisbury steak, and i ended up spending probably  over a hour just trying to make this sauce decent, i ended up putting a bunch of honey bbq sauce, a lot of steak sauce, a couple teaspoons of garlic, salt & pepper, about a tbs of lemon juice. cream of mushroom soup, and a lot of montreal steak seasoning, just to make it edible then when i ate it i didn't use much of the sauce on it i let the sauce run off of it, like a lot of people i baked it for about 20 minutes at 400 i hope this saves a lot of people time on not using this sauce i would of just used beef gravy if i would of read the reviews first. but the meat turned out very well i would suggest  this to people with young kids or elders that have problems eating cause it turns out with a very soft texture

Next time, I will use dry soup mix in the meat, and I will take my time putting the gravy together.

I've made this recipe exactly as directed, and made the version with the mushroom soup (using a can of French Onion soup as well as a can of Cream of Mushroom and a packet of Dry Onion Soup for the gravy and doubling the remaining gravy ingredients except the ketchup; browned on stove and then cooked the steaks in oven for 45 minutes along with the gravy.)  I loved the tangy ketchupy taste of the original version but my son really loved the mushroon soup version!  Either way,we love this recipe and will continue to make it often!  Thanks!

region:

country:
None
text:
This isn't a bad recipe, just not at all what I was expecting. If you are trying to make standard Salisbury steak -- with the sort of flavor that comes in frozen entrees or in restaurants -- use onion soup mix for the flavoring and nothing else, as so many reviewers have suggested.  Catsup makes it taste like Swiss steak, the Worcestershire doesn't belong, and absolutely no mustard powder.  Browned mine in a pan then baked for 30 min at 325, was very tender and juicy. Family ate it, but asked for the old way next time.

I only gave this recipe a 4 instead of 5 stars because of the changes that I feel improve the recipe. The 2nd time I, too, added onion and garlic to the meat mixture and mushroom soup to the gravy mixture. Took some other reviewers advice and nixed the ketchup. Sauteed onions and mixed with the meat. text:
My wife and I made this and really enjoyed it. I gave it four stars because I did feel the need to tweak it just a bit. Like other reviewers, I added a can of cream of mushroom to the gravy. Also, I used a bit more onion soup than called for in my meat and let the patties rest before browning in an already-hot cast iron skillet, which prevented the crumbling that other reviewers have reported. All in all, definitely a repeater!

I am rating this with 4 stars because I completely botched this recipe. I mixed the entire can of French onion soup with the beef mixture and I didn't have regular bread crumbs on hand, so I used seasoned bread crumbs... even with that these "steaks" turned out pretty darn good.  Obviously, I didn't have any soup mix left to make the gravy so I ended up using a few things I had on hand (beef gravy and steak sauce) to create my own.  So this recipe only gets 4 stars because I goofed...however, it is a testament that this recipe is fool-proof!

text:
Well, I rated this 4* b/c MY recipe came out wonderful!  I didn't have ketchup so I substituted a BBQ sauce; I DON'T use prepkgd soups so I added my own sautéed onions and since I knew what the recipe was looking for:  flavor, I added anchovies (umami) to the beef.  The sauce was definitely not enough, but still was good, I also added a bit of beef broth.  I will make it again but w/double some of the ingredients.  And still NO pkgd foods, they contain MSG which is not good ladies & gents!  Oh, I did add a non MSG bouillon to the gravy and in help it dissolve, heated the water!  We CAN all cook, and when we don't have the ingredients called for, we can IMPROVISE!!!

text:
I'm puzzled as to why I found this listed under Dairy-free, condensed French onion soup is not a dairy-free product. I had to make variations due to that factor using a soup mix instead, which didn't make it bad. My family, especially my significant other who is dairy-free, absolutely loved it. I am not in love w/ this recipe but it appears I will be making it often. I'm going to make more adjustments. The ketchup makes this dish seem sketchy smelling. Don't fear it if you base your eating mostly off of smell (I do!) because you may be deceived with this dish.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Low Fat version of recipe still very tasty! By using low-fat versions of ingredients I reduced this 32 grams of fat per serving recipe down to only 6 grams of fat! I utilized the same recipe except I substituted certain ingredients with their low-fat versions. I used 97% reduced fat beef, very lean, I used 98% fat free cream of mushroom (added to recipe based on other's recommendations) and it reduced the fat content substantially and still had a great taste! I personally would use half the amount of Worcestershire sauce if you are not a big fan of it like me. Other than that, great recipe, great meal!

text:
My husband loved this dish! I did change one thing. I added double to the sauce mix. It just wasn't enough sauce the first time I made this. The second time I made this I made more sauce by using 2 french onion soup cans and also added 2 cans cream of mushroom soup. The differences were more sauce and the meat was softer than when I made it with less sauce. Also, I sauteed onions, mushroom, and garlic with the meat. It was delicious!

country:

text:
I've made this recipe several times as-is and everyone loves it. The gravy doesn't have the typical brown gravy flavor, which is why I think some reviewers don't like it as much. I once added a packet of brown gravy seasoning and a little water to the gravy and it obviously gave it a much more traditional brown gravy flavor. I assume adding a packet of onion soup mix would do the same. Either way my family loves it. It's also very easy and quick to make, which is another bonus.

I thought this was fantastic! Apart from the meat being soggy :-/ Not sure what that was from but I followed everything perfectly, but tweeked the sauce. Once the patties were cooked I took them out of the pan, sprinkled some flour and cooked that into a roux. Then I added a little milk, just a tish of mustard and ketchup and added the remaining french onion soup. Let it thicken a bit, placed the patties back in the pan and enjoyed! :-D

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh wow! This was incredibly good! The ONLY changes I made to this was that I used EXTRA LEAN ground beef specifically, comes out most tender; I knew this because I use the same type to make my Italian meatballs (my Italian Grandmother taught me this). I added extra water (about a half of a cup) with an additional tablespoon of flour stirred into the water then poured into the already cooking gravy in the pan; made more gravy. Brought the gravy and steaks to a boil, reduced to LOW and simmered slowly, covered, for an hour or so - stirring every 15 mins. My husband loved it but said the gravy reminded him of catsup (shhhh! I didn't tell him that was one of the ingredients!), so next time I will probably reduce that ingredient by half. Still, I give this recipe 5 stars because it was awesome!!! These are so much better than the store bought Salisbury Steaks, by a million!

text:
To make this dairy-free, I used 2 packages of lipton soup mix with 20 oz of water.  I also used just 1 pound of ground beef (cutting back on the bread crumbs to 1/3 c) and doubled the rest of the ingredients for the gravy (but not the katsup or mustard powder). I also added some ground pepper to the gravy along with a tsp of granulated beef bullion. I made it the way others have by baking it for 30 mins at 400. It was great and my son could eat it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave it 4 stars only because I changed the gravy.  This is the second time I have made it, and we really like it.  The gravy is very forgiving if you use what you like best.  I added a little bit of beefy onion soup mix (about 1/3 of a packet) to the called for ingredients and used 2 lbs of ground beef .  For the gravy I used the rest of the french onion condensed soup, a can of golden mushroom, and a jar of beef gravy.  I omited all salt because the ingredients are a salty enough by themselves.  I also added a half can of water.  I served with mashed potatoes.  Thank you for the recipe!

I just made this recipe and it was delicious! Except I altered it to be healthier with wheat flour, virgin olive oil to brown the meat, sea salt and my personal meat seasoning which includes meat tenderizer, mrs dash table salt, garlic salt, and lemon pepper. Plus barsely. Then instead of cooking it in a skillet after browning, I followed a comment on the reviews here by putting them in a oven pan and cooking it at 300 for 30mins to prevent the patties from falling apart and it worked! My family loved it! Plan to make it again and again! ;D

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Easy..yes. Tasty? Not so much. It was quite bland. I added one whole chopped onion on top of the gravy after browning to give it a more chunky gravy (DO NOT SAUTEE BEFORE, it will burn the onion). Recipe calls to make 6 patties, I made 7. Also added garlic pepper, spicy creole seasoning, and shoved some crushed garlic cloves inside the steaks for more flavor. The gravy should be tripled, wasn't enough to serve for all 7 steaks AND mashed potatoes (i made rosemary mashed potatoes, which was a good hint of some nature with the steak). All in all, good for a starter salisbury steak, but not good by itself.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe, though, I did change it slightly. I omitted the ketchup in favor of Open Pit original BBQ sauce. I'm not a ketchup fan and the BBQ sauce added a slight tangy flavor but it was delicious. I also played around with the amount of soup and bread crumbs for the meat mixture adding slightly more than called for. The first few times I made this I formed the meat into patties like it says, but this last time I made a meatloaf out of it and it came out perfect. I cooked it in a 350 degree oven for 1 hour and 20 minutes. I dumped the sauce(I doubled the amount of sauce) right in the pan with it and every 20 minutes or so would spoon the sauce over the top of the loaf. When it was done it had a nice glaze and was delicious.

city:

country:
None
text:
We loved this recipe. I did follow the others advice and use 1 can of condensed golden cream of mushroom and 1 packet of brown gravy in addition to the condensed french onion soup. I did pan fry them some then baked @400 for 30 mins then brought it down to 350 for another 30 minutes all in the gravy. At first the gravy/sauce tasted a little off but as it baked it really meshed well together. It was delicious and my husband keeps reminding me to put it on our menu options list. Next time I will try it with the origional recipe. I initially thought the onion flavor might be too strong with 2 cans of the onion and hubby might not like it. I would deffinetly recommed doubling the sauce if serving with mashed potatoes as we did. SOOOO yummy! Thanks for the recipe, it's a keeper!

text:
I loved this it was quick and easy and very tasty.  I had to improvise based on what I had in the house.  I had no condensed onion soup so I used a can of cream of mushroom soup and added a pack of onion soup mix to it.  I used the remainder of that mixture for the gravy with 2 beef bouillon cubes and water and cornstarch to thicken.  I also had no breadcrumbs and used crushed up butter crackers.  It was so good and sooo easy.

text:
I'd have liked to have given this 3.5 stars if I could it's not quite a four star dish for me, but it was still tasty. I could not find the condensed soup required so used ordinary French Onion soup. Because of that I didn't add any to the meat as it would have made the burgers too sloppy. I followed the recipe as stated otherwise, to give it a fair trial. I was afraid that the sauce would taste too much of tinned soup, but I couldn't detect it at all, maybe because the ketchup flavour was too prominent. Next time I will definately reduce the amount of ketchup used. This is one I will need to tinker with, but is a very good base.

This is a GREAT tasting recipe. It doesn't taste like TV dinner steaks. It has its own unique flavor that is delicious!  I wanted to add some golden mushroom soup to the gravy, but the store was out so I bought beefy mushroom instead. One of the best recipes I have found on this site.

text:
I did the meat as it was written. I browner the meat on both sides then put the patties in a baking pan. I followed the gravy recipe except I didn't add the water then I add one can of cream of mushroom soup, two jars of savory beef fat free gravy, garlic powder and onion powder. I put the gravy over the meat, covered it with foil then baked it at 400 for 45 min. Turned out better then I thought.

Wow!  I was searching for a salisbury steak recipe mainly for my college age son, he loves salisbury steak with gravy.  This recipe seemed easy enough and the reviews were pretty good.  I made it the other night for dinner and it was a hit, my husband and younger son gave it 2 thumbs up!  I followed the recipe except I added a bit of garlic powder to the meat mixture, and I doubled the gravy portion as others had suggested.  The patties were very moist with a really good flavor.  I was a little worried about the gravy being too tangy with the ketchup/worcestershire sauce as some have said, but I thought it had a great flavor.  I can't wait to make it for my other son when he comes home for spring break!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-02-26T17:45:02.917

My husband loved this.  I followed some suggestions and cut the ketchup in half.  I also browned in frying pan and then put in foil lined casserole dish (poured gravy on top) and baked at 400 for 45 minutes.  It is a keeper.

text:
When I decided to make this recipie our local store was out of french onion soup so I used an altered recipie someone else posted with Golden Mushroom soup and take out the ketchup. It was PERFECT! I would give it a 5 star. I tried it again with 100% the original recipie (french onion and ketchup) and we threw just about all of it out, no one liked it. I would say the meat and style in which it is prepared is perfect, but the flavors of the sauce will make of break this dish, so I gave it a 3. The recipie I wrote down in my book was altered to exclude ketchup, use Golden Mushroom soup and double the sauce to put over mashed potatoes.

text:
Really enjoyed this one.  We normally buy the frozen salisbury steaks and were ready for a change.  The meat was moist and tender and very tasty.  I was a little worried though, when most of my gravy mix was either soaked up in the meat or cooked off.  So after removing the meat from the pan I added another 1/4 cup of water to the drippings so that we would have enough gravy for the meat and our mashed potatoes.  I am thinking I will probably double the gravy next time and maybe add some fresh mushrooms :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I skipped putting the ketchup in at all because of other reviews and it just didn't sound good to me.  I did add a little more worcestershire than it called for maybe 4 tablespoons.  After mixing up the gravy before I put it in the pan I added just one can of cream of mushroom soup to the mixture because what was called for just didn't seem like enough.  Also I sliced up 5 fresh mushrooms and put it in with the gravy.  This turned out really good.  My fiance who said he doesn't even care for salisbury steak went back for seconds.  The next time I try it I will make sure to drain the hamburger patties really really good before simmering with the gravy because it turned out a little too greasy for us.  I didn't have any problems with the steaks falling apart.  I think the trick is not to "handle" or flip them too much.  We really did enjoy it and I do recommend this recipe!
