text:
i could not find french onion soup so i just bought a packet of onion soup from walmart (i'm cheap). i added 1/2 of the dry mix to the beef mixture and the other 1/2 to 4 cups of water along with a packet of beef vegetable soup mix (it has noodles) and cooked it. when the soup was cooked i added 1/4 of it to the beef mixture. i added the rest of the cooked soup to the gravy mix and also a tin of mushrooms. (i also doubled everything but the ketchup like other reviewers mentioned and deleted the salt) the beef i made into patties and cooked them until the tops were browned (the inside was still pink) on the george foreman grill and then added them to the gravy mix and cooked it on medium for 20 minutes. was delish and am adding it to my dinner rotation.

So Good! My  husband and picky children loved this dish!  I increased the gravy  by doubling everthing but the ketchup(as suggested). I added 1 cup of fresh sliced mushrooms and sauteed with after the onions were soft, which I put on top of the browned patties and then into a preheated 325 degree oven covered for 30 min, they turned out perfect. Paired nicely with homemade mashed potatoes and a salad. Will make again for sure!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I mixed the patties with the breadcrumbs, 1/2 of the french onion soup, garlic powder and onion powder, sauteed them on the stove, then sauteed some mushrooms and onions and put the patties and the onions/mushrooms in an oven dish.   This rating is based on the patties as I did not want to use the ketchup/soup/dry soup mixture for the sauce. I deglazed the pan with some beef broth and because I didn't want to waste the other 1/2 of the french onion soup I added that in, then added some light cream and a dollop of dijon mustard and cornstarch to thicken it up. The patties doused in this sauce made them edible. Everyone ate theirs but didn't go back for seconds.

I was not a fan of the tangy taste to the sauce, so I added on teaspoon of cornstartch and just enough water to disolve it in a cup, and stirred it into the sauce, once thickened a bit I added 1 1/2 cups of water and 1 1/2 teaspoons of beef boullion to it to give more sauce and a more meaty flavor and my family just loves it.

text:
I thought this was pretty good recipe to start with.  Needed quite a bit of tweaking but that's ok, I rarely go strictly by the recipe I like to add my own personal touch. I added the cream of mushroom soup as suggested by other reviews and onion/mushroom dried soup mix. But that made it quite salty so I balanced that with some red wine,a little water (my sauce was pretty thick) more pepper and some bay leaf and thyme dried herbs.
I havent eaten yet just been sampling the gravy!  But I also did as suggested and browned the patty's in skillet and then put the patties in a pyrex dish and put in the oven with the gravy poured over.  Tastes pretty good so far and I think the family will like it.
I havent made Salisbury steak in a long, long time but it sounded good and I am very happy to have found this recipe.

country:
None
text:
Delicious! I didn't know that making Salisbury Steak would be so easy. I added chopped onions to the meat mixture; didn't have a can of french onion, so I substituted with 1/3 a can of beef consumme. Took patties out of pan when browned, added mushrooms, then deglazed pan with remaining beef consumme and added additional can. In bowl mixed together 2 cans of Cream of Mushroom soup, 2 pkg of onion soup mix, plus doubled all gravy ingredients except ketchup. Added that to pan and mixed with consumme. Then added patties back to mix and cooked 20 min. Served with Mashed Potatoes and green beans

This recipe was soooooooooooo good!  I had never made Salisbury Steak before, except those frozen nasty things, so I was totally clueless on how this was going to taste.  It was really good!  I would definitely make more sauce next time though as this was not enough.  I did accidentally put way too much powdered mustard in the sauce, but it was still excellent.  I am sure it would be even better with the right amount.  My 2 year old usually eats mostly veggies and pasta.  She is not a meat eater and she hates potatoes of any kind.  I still give them to her when I make them because I don't want a picky eater.  Anyway, she ate a half of a serving of the steak and all of the potatoes with the gravy!  She absolutely loved it and after every bite, she would say Ummm!!!! and rub her belly!  You have to try this recipe!

This was a good recipe!  I think the meat could have used a bit more seasoning, but the sauce was surprisingly yummy. I did make a couple of sauce changes: I didn't have mustard powder, so I put a little bit of yellow mustard in it. Also, there didn't seem to be enough sauce for my liking, so I also added a packet of brown gravy and some water to make the sauce very thin.  It thickened up perfectly as it cooked.

text:
I had no issues with this recipe!  The only addition I made was adding onion to the ground beef, but that's something I do for everything I make.

The ketchup does give its own flavor, so it you aren't a fan of ketchup, omit it.

The patties didn't fall apart too much as long as I allowed them to brown on each side before attempting to flip, and instead of a metal spatula I used a heat safe icing spreader.  It didn't rip at the meat like my metal spatula did.

I, too, believe it is unfair to rate a recipe you have not tried in its original form first. However, that being said, I will say that this is, for my family, a 5 star recipe. Salisbury steak as my dad makes it has always been my "most favorite meal" and I beg him to make it for me every chance I get. I tried this version (on my own, without that pesky begging business) and thought it was very, very tasty. I may post my dad's version and then everyone can rate that separately. (His is very close to a lot of the "fixes" many posters suggested) I will not go into how he does it differently here because it is a somewhat different recipe. I loved this one too and believe it is worth 5 stars!

I don't think I'll be making this again but if I do I'll add milk to the soup before making the gravy.

region:

country:
None
text:
I have used this recipe more times than I can count, and it is a huge hit every time. I've prepared it for many guests and everyone who tastes it raves about how delicious it is!

I love to make this recipe and freeze it. You can freeze the patties and gravy together in one Ziploc bag, or put them in seperate bags and containers, then reheat them in a large frying pan over medium heat. Delicious.

Edited:
I now have to triple this recipe to feed our entire family. The skillet isn't big enough to simmer that many patties. For a crowd like ours, brown the patties in shifts, then put them all in a large baking dish. Cover with gravy and keep in the oven at 250-300 while you put together the rest of the meal and wash your cookware. It turns out great.

text:
While this recipe is excellent and quite easy, I would DEFINITELY NOT cook the steaks by pan.  They fell apart slightly.  I would place them while raw, as formed patties, into a casserole with a thin layer of gravy underneath them. I would cover them with another thin layer, place tin foil over the casserole and bake until they are cooked through.  Then, prior to serving, I would heat up the gravy and pour over.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very good recipe. I used just under a pound of ground beef and kept the rest of the recipe the same. I made seven smaller sized patties, and since other reviewers mentioned the patties falling apart I made sure I was very careful flipping them. I had to use a turkey baster to drain off the excess grease since I couldn't really move them too much without them flaking. Anyway, they turned out very good, moist and flavorful. I was worried about the mustard and horseradish overpowering the sauce or giving it a strong taste, but you couldn't really tell it had those in it. It was very good, very easy and I will definately make this again.

text:
New family fav. I use venison burger to lower fat and we had a great hunting season! Definitly double the sauce. Can't find French Onion soup, use cream of onion or cream of mushroom and add a packet of Lipton dry onion soup mix right to the sauce. Sometimes I do half ketchup and half Open Pit BBQ sauce.  Optional: add mushrooms, chopped tomatoes, diced green peppers.  Very versitile recipe.  Our kids don't like texture of steak, but they eat this right up every time.  Great gravy on mashed potatoes.

text:
My family loves this recipe. I cook the patties on the stove top until brown, and then bake them in a 350 degree oven, covered, for about 25 minutes. As for the sauce, I omit the ketchup and add a little more water and a packet of brown gravy mix. Sometimes I also add a can of cream of mushroom soup to that. It just depends on if I want a mushroom gravy or a brown gravy. Either way is great.

Thanks for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We love this recipe!  It does not taste like I expect Salisbury Steak to taste, but we love it anyway.  I have been making this dish for two years now.  For the 1/3 cup soup that goes in the meat, I spoon out most of the onions from the can.  This reduces the liquid in the meat (helping them hold together) and helps keep the sauce smooth.  I also add 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire and 2 tablespoons of ketchup to the meat mixture before browning, since I like the flavor of the sauce to carry through the meat.  This is one of the few things I make that my husband specifically requests.  Thank you!

text:
Awesome salisbury steak! I make the gravy different: saute some sliced mushrooms in equal parts olive oil and butter until soft, add salt and pepper to taste, add flour (how much depends on how thick you like it, I use 4T)whisk in beef stock, cook until thick,add beef patties back to pan to keep warm.

text:
This recipe is amazing. A little too tangy for me, but I still gobbled it up. I used regular mustard instead of the pwdr, and doubled everything except for the ketchup and mustard; next time I'll use even less. I also used a beef broth with a pckt of onion soup instead of the kind the recipe calls for. And I only browned the patties for a few mins. on each side, and then broiled them in the oven for 15 mins. I also added tons of mushrooms. YUM!!

country:
None
text:
This is an excellent recipe.  I made a few changes based on the recommendations of others.  To the meat mixture I added 1/4 C of the canned French onion soup and 1/2 pkg dry onion soup mix and 1 tsp of Worcestershire and omitted salt. (everthing else the same)  For the gravy I used rest of canned onion soup, about 1 Tbsp ketchup, a beef boullion cube and a small can of mushrooms. (everything else the same.) This is the best salisbury steak I have ever had.  Great with mashed potatoes!

text:
I tried this recipe this week and my family loved it.  I made it with ground chuck rather than the ground beef.  Also, for the venison eaters, I had a package of cubed deer steaks that I floured, browned and then added to the skillet of salisbury steak.  I let everything simmer for about 1-1/2 hours and it was delicious.  Even my husband who usually will not eat venison commented on how good both were.  Incidently, I doubled the gravy so we would have plenty to serve over rice.  I will definitely be using this recipe again.  I also shared the recipe with the girls in my office.  Thanks for sharing this with us.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe! I didn't have any canned onion soup so I made some from a recipe here on the site, Rich and Simple French Onion Soup. I used it to make this recipe. Wonderful! No leftovers, everyone cleaned their plate. The sauce is habit forming. I will be making this a lot. Thanks for sharing it. Feb. 2010 made this for the umpteenth time, just incredible.  Made my own soup again too. Everyone cleaned their plates, even the Greys! 
Yes, African Grey Parrots eat people food. 
Doubled the sauce as always, but do not double the ketchup. Some tomato is needed in beef dishes, brings out the flavors and makes them richer but don't overdo it. Used some thyme and sage, just 1/4 tsp. each, went really lite on the salt, it can get very salty very fast so watch it. If you must use bouillon cubes don't add any other salt at all. One clove of garlic in with the onion soup. Really no other major adjustments. Mashed taters, green beans and homemade rolls, just doesn't get any better.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2001-10-28T12:49:34.23
helpfulCount:
